author: {'steamid': '76561198273771273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1660969225}
review:
Very fun, Very smooth. Nice Variety in weapons and special ablities (perks). Sometimes it's a little hard to see enemies or maybe that's just me. The player hitbox is a little too big IMO but maybe I'm just bad.

7/10 Play it if you like top down shoot'em ups

author: {'steamid': '76561197992387895', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1791, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1304, 'last_played': 1628274200}
review:
I've played Crimsonland back in the old days of yore when the coolest thing to do was to go to the library and hop on runescape for an hour. Seeing it revamped and redistributed with a cleaner HUD and more game modes has definitely made it worth purchasing once again.

I definitely enjoy the new game modes, especially the typing game mode (something I feel more arcade style games like this should have in it). But if I were to mention something I've found annoying about it was the fact that during Survival mode, after around 200,000 points are reached, the monsters are so quick, and many of them are buffed so much that it renders gauss weapons ineffective as there's no more piercing happening. You have to rely on either ion weapons, or if you've completed the quest mode on the hardest difficulty, The Splitter.

That aside I hope that someday the person behind this game takes another fresh look at it and improves it even further, maybe get experimental with it a tad. Or even, perhaps, find a way to make it moddable so that the community can tinker around in it a bit and make their own fun.

All in all a great arcade shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978573721', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1597, 'last_played': 1669688410}
review:
Really one of top favorites.  Now only have the devs brought the game over intact from non-Steam shareware, but the game has had tweaks and updates that show they want it to continue.
I won't go over all the reasons why it works 'just so', but mainly it's the subtle line between being able to hold your own and the freakout of being overrun by various vicious varmints.
Ranking system, stats has a better interface than business products!  Look at the player names, I hope you'll get a laugh out of them like I have.
Even the little peek at new titles at the main menu is well done.
No x out of y ranking here, simply a Very Recommended buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073166350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1834, 'last_played': 1635647540}
review:
Ahhh Crimsonland! I've played it off and on since it was first released thru Reflexive Arcade back in '03. Which is also the source of the "reflex boosted" powerup icon, if anyone didn't know =) I've bought this game a number of times on a number of platforms since then, and will happily buy it again if it comes out on some other thing I own! Where do I even start...

Graphics - 3/5 No, they aren't spectacular compared to many...or any...of the AAA titles that have come out in the last few years. It is a top down, twin stick shooter, what are you really expecting here? Everything can be clearly and easily identified, and doesn't hurt to look at. Nothing spectacular, but then...I doubt that's what anyone was going for. Good enough really is good enough!

Story - lol/wtf Once upon a time, there was a guy standing in the middle of a field for no reason. For no reason, aliens and spiders and beetles and zombies all started running at him. For equally no reason, all sorts of guns and powerups appear from the corpses of these things. Guy kills things until the reaper gets him. That's it, that's a summary of the story, narrative, and all the characters. What, were you expecting some Dickensian struggle? Some moral dilemma? Nope. Top down. Twin stick. Shooter. Kill things until you die. That's it, that's all there really needs to be for the genre.

Sound - 4/5 Both at home and at work, for varying reasons, I play without sound usually. However, I do really like the soundtrack for Crimsonland! Best described with *slow heavy metal music plays*. It fits the rest of the game experience, without being too repetitive or irritating. My wife dislikes all the gunfire...sorry, can't be helped lol! The death sound is great for laughs tho!

Controls - 5/5 It is, as stated, a top down twin stick shooter. The controls are intuitive and responsive, simple and complete, easy to change. I see no way this could have been better.

Balance - 3/5 Good difficulty curve, except for any level involving spideroids. Seriously, fuck those things.

Gameplay - 5/5 Over the years, me and my employees have sunk literally thousands of combined hours into this game, between survival, and some of the hidden minigames. There is the right combination of luck and skill and planning involved to make different playthrus feel actually different and not repetitive. Hell, the monster spawns are more or less "procedural" and random in survival, maybe they can cash in on the "roguelike" tag that has become so abused and misused lately ;)

Overall - 4/5 Balance in the campaign mode gets a bit rough in places, but overall, this is a very solid offering for the genre. Price is right. A great buy for any fan of the genre!

author: {'steamid': '76561198055712441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 83, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1503243724}
review:
Crimsonland ist ein echt guter Top Down Shooter.

Die Grafik ist in diesem Spiel neben Sache, finde sie aber okay.

Das Gameplay ist einfach erklÃ¤rt, da man einfach alles abballert was man sieht. Es gibt einen Quest Modus (so eine Art Story Modus) und den Survival Modus der verschiedene Modi enthÃ¤lt (Survival, Rush etc.). Das gibt dem Spiel richtig Abwechslung, da es auch verschiedene Gegner Typen und Gegner StÃ¤rken gibt.

Crimsonland emphele ich defenitiv weiter wenn man mal nicht weiss was man spielen soll :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028759306', 'num_games_owned': 4193, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 4455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1505, 'last_played': 1642951213}
review:
First of all, I kinda liked new game (beat all levels without a scratch and placed in first 500 players in all survival modes), despite developers made everything for it to be inferior to 2003 1.9.8.2 version, which I still will sometime play after I uninstalled new one.

Of course concerning removed perks - why protagonist in main menu shooting monsters with 2 guns in each of his hands, while in game not only you cannot fire with 2 weapons simultaniously, you even can't have secondary alternate weapon as in 2003 version.

While my complaint is somewhat humorous and too far-fetched, I'd just really want to say as a Crimsonalnd veteran - it really takes some skill to make a game in 2017 worse than it was almost 15 years ago.

Still It helped to kill 25 hours of my time so overall thumbs up

author: {'steamid': '76561198034775049', 'num_games_owned': 535, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 7916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2279, 'last_played': 1675441714}
review:
Great little game. I decided to write a review, because of how unpopular this game is. Last time I checked on steam charts there were less than 50 people playing in 24h.
The game itself is very simple. You shoot stuff. There's about 40 campaign missions on two difficulties, that you have to complete to unlock every weapon and perk possible. There are plenty of weapons and the diversity is fine at most. You still end up using only very few best weapons. There's also a lot of perks to choose from when you level up. You get to choose from 4 randomly selected ones.
The game really shines on survivals though. I found myself playing over and over trying to beat highscore, play different weapons or get luckier in rng perks.
The visuals are good, everything is clear and simplistic, the gun sounds are nice aswell. I only wish there were more tracks than one and multiplayer. Right now you can only play local up to 4 players and surviving with friends would be a blast. Cool game for 5 minutes if you don't have time aswell as for long hours grinding score.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061103280', 'num_games_owned': 788, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1577569235}
review: Simply the best top-down shooter there is.  Perfect controls, huge variety of power-ups and a very rewarding upgrade system.  Levels are difficult but not frustrating (survival mode is the ultimate challenge).  Just an all-around great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053347381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1498337786}
review:
While I personally prefer this on my Xbox One, this is a classic. It sticks to the classic arcade feeling, and if you mainly play this for the survival mode as I do (Blitz on xbox, though I've not unlocked it here yet) it's a blast. The Quests to unlock all the stuff can certainly be challenging. Fast-paced, simple, and fun. 
Note that there is some RNG in this game. This mainly comes about in perk choices as you level up (think Dota, you level up every game from zero) but for the most part you get used to spawns and stuff. If you're one to aim for high scores, this helps that feeling.
All in all this is one of those solid games I'd have to give a 9/10 for its presentation and what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970360141', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1695760168}
review:
An absolute classic. Crimsonland was my first "top-down action shooter" of this sort. Super Contra/Super C are the earliest examples of this sort of play, and Serious Sam came out a few years before, which could reasonably be considered a relative, as well. But having the top down mode, waves of differing baddies, a huge variety of powerups and alternate weapons, and requiring very quick thinking and decisionmaking in a highly satisfying package was ALL Crimsonland's doing.

There've been many successors since then. Alien Shooter by Sigma Team added a much more fully realized campaign, Shadowgrounds by Frozenbyte was the first finished game in this style presented in 3d. Even Valve got on the bandwagon with Alien Swarm, in a way. 

Crimsonland may not have been THE first to do everything it does, but it was definitely MY first. So certainly I have a bit of bias here, but I think it's well-earned bias, at the very least. The core of it is extremely simple and requires very little learning. Move, shoot monsters, grab powerups, don't die. The wide assortment of weapons, enemy types, and powerups means that you're constantly reevaluating everything you're doing as the situation changes, playing defensively at times, offensively at others, trying desperately to avoid picking up the dreaded blowtorch...

It's a very satisfying package all around. Everything just feels good, it's proper fun. I recommend everybody interested in quick-thinking action check out Crimsonland. It's one of my favorites, and maybe it'll be one of yours too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065706778', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1692105940}
review:
A game that is more than a decade old, but still relevant. Here are some awesome features:
 - 55 perks  
 - 30 unique weapons
 - Four-player local co-op !!!
 - Five game mods  
 - A quest mod equipped with six chapters  
 - Tearing the enemies to shreds with versatile guns and huge amounts of blood.
 
While all of these features are awesome, the game also comes with some drawbacks: 
 - obsolete graphics and some huge empty and a bit boring arenas
 - the absence of perks in the Quest mode; they are present only in the Survival mode
 - basic methods of enemy grouping, well-known gameplay
 - unbalanced difficulty in some Survival mode situations, where a huge wave of enemies attacks that is impossible to be destroyed
 - occasional spawning of the enemies on the top of the player, which results in instant death

It is still golden in many regards, and it has lots of content. Worthy addition to your game library especially if you are a fan of shmup games.

If you are looking for other interesting shmupgames, I would like to invite you to our community group on Steam:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/593680

http://store.steampowered.com/app/593680/Rocking_Pilot/

author: {'steamid': '76561197991559968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 587, 'last_played': 1696103342}
review: This was the first indie game I ever bought back in early 2000's. I dumped probably about 100 hours into this game back then. Arcade twin-stick monster shooter. The campaign quest are rather trivial on the first difficulty but you have to get a bit more creative with perk and weapon selection once you get into hardcore and above. The new survival modes are really fun and great for couch co-op with friends.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062057359', 'num_games_owned': 808, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2763, 'last_played': 1484542024}
review:
To preface this, I won this on steamgifts.com and I accidentally left it on overnight once which ended up with almost 24 hours more time then I actually spent in game.

Crimsonland is a very simple top down shooter (twin stick), almost the most simple basic arcade version of the genre.  It is a level based game where the enemies spawn around the map and you must simply survive by killing everything on the map.

The core gameplay is very simple: point, click, enemies die, and dodge enemies.  There isn't much else to this game, it has a progression system by unlocking guns that do various different things.  It feels good when you beat a hard level, but I don't know it just isn't very complex. 

I would give it a 4/5 but one of the achievements is to get a fairly high score in a 2048 like game that is hidden, so it gets a 3/5 for being stupid.  I would only get it if you want a game that is mostly mindless fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 787, 'last_played': 1643037995}
review:
Tags: Top Down Shooter - Arena

TLDR: A very solid entry in the genre. Highly recommended

Pros:
+Xbox360 Support - Good Default button Layout / Resolution Options - Some Gameplay Options
+Sweet sound design overall
+Consistent polish over bullet tracings, blood splatters protag and foe sprites menus lighting effects and power up icons
+Story mode with RPG style char progression and progressively more difficult arenas and endless challenge mode for score attacks
+Local Co-Op (4)
+Shooting mechanics are very solid and satisfying. Life and death feels earned and deserved.

Cons:
+Could had used different protags with strenghts and weaknesses
+No real story to speak of
+Could have had even more audiovisual flair for a 2014 release

author: {'steamid': '76561198282688828', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1561672435}
review:
Let's start off with the pro's

~Pro's

~A lot of gun's to pick from
~Good for throwing a few hour's every day in to it
~Good controls
~Look's good for what it is
~Good price of what it is
~Fun with friend's
~Even a crapy computer (Like mine) can run it with no problem's

~Con's

~get's a little boring if you play it to much
~could have a better campaige


All in all it's a really fun game, i like it a lot, i can't really think of anything that i hate about it or dislike
100% Should get this game!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004536710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1645591901}
review:
It's hard for me to find anything bad to say about Crimsonland, for a number of reasons.  One of them is, I'll admit, I've been playing it off and on since..around over 10 years ago?  I don't remember when it came out, but a buddy of mine showed it to me and we played it constantly.  So there's some nostalgia and attachment there for me.

But I'm honestly surprised that, as old as it is at this point, it still has received updates in the past few years.  

Crimsonland is a top-down shooter, fast paced and at times brutal, but in a fun die-click-repeat-die again till you win kind of fashion.  It's one of those great time killer games, where maybe you want to play something cool, but don't have time to fire up something as cool as The Witcher 3 for example, and just need to get in a quick fix.

There are several modes to choose from, plenty of weapons and perks to unlock, and for what it's worth, there are leaderboards, but I don't pay much attention to those personally.  The music is decent and fits the game, though I usually opt to put on something from my personal collection if I'm gonna go a few rounds, which suits me just fine.  Some modes I don't really care about, but to each their own.  Survival is by far my favorite.  

Give it a try.  It's worth the modest asking price.  It's cheap, fun, and addictive.  If you enjoy this, I'd also recommend Neon Chrome by the same developer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044574299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 152, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 152, 'last_played': 1495785473}
review:
Decent little top-down shooter.

Pro
- vast range of weapons
- rocket minigun (yes, it is)
- easy start followed with challenging later levels
- sea of gore
- other game modes, including one where you have to type the letters to make your dude shoot
- co-op mode

Con
- short, the first run lasts about 3 hours
- Apart from the missions, I do not feel the need to try the other modes, or run through the campaign again on higher difficulty. But that is my taste, you might like it very much.

Value

7/10 A good choice if you want a little shooter game for a buck. Bad choice if you want some AAA title or spend more than 2 USD/EUR.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009654132', 'num_games_owned': 2910, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1495618142}
review:
Crimsonland is a scorefest twinstick-shooter with lots of fun.

Pros:
+ Fun, game throws a fair challenge with lots of option
+ Gfx palette, it blends well and easy on the eye. Its easy to spot projectiles and enemies
+ Controls, it is mostly overlooked but controls in this game makes it a classic

Neutral
~ Production values, it is becoming old and started to show its age
~ Longevity, it is harsh to expect something like that from a game like this but, after a while scoregasm is not enough to keep you playing it, not enough content

Cons
- Soundtrack, its repetitive and gets boring fast

7/10 When scoregasmic twin-stick shooters is the matter, this game is still fun. Do not expect nothing more from it. It is what it is and it does it's job good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086162912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1596952069}
review:
Crimsonland is one of my favorite games for racking up crazy scores. It's satisfying as hell. Unfortunately, at least when it comes to survival mode, a good run depends greatly on luck. Getting the right perks at the right times is vitally important to getting a high score. It doesn't matter how skilled you are. If you don't have the perks, you simply will not pump out enough damage to stem the overwhealming tide. 

This makes the survival mode very much a game of luck. I don't think this detracts too much from the appeal of the game though. Just don't expect a pure skill experience like Geometry Wars.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999498546', 'num_games_owned': 8364, 'num_reviews': 235, 'playtime_forever': 3541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3451, 'last_played': 1494731002}
review:
Crimsonland is a classic top-down twin-stick shooter. The game focuses on the important things of the genre like good controls and fluent gameplay even with massive amounts of enemies on the screen, and skips uninteresting things, like a Story.  
       
[b][h1]Controls:[/h1][/b]
And since we are at it, the controls are smooth and working precise at any given moment. I played the game with keyboard and mouse. I havenâ€™t tried it with my controller yet. 
         
[b][h1]Technic:[/h1][/b]
In my whole time with the game I never had any stutters or fps drops. The game ran smoosh at any given time, even when the whole screen was filled with enemies and effects.
           
[b][h1]Story:[/h1][/b]
shoot shoot pew pew : )
        
[b][h1]Gameplay:[/h1][/b]
The game offers seven different game modes which splinted in two categories â€œQuestâ€ and â€œSurvivalâ€. 
In the quest mode, you have 6 chapters with 10 levels each which are getting harder constantly. Also you can unlock two additional difficulties if you have beaten the levels on normal.
In the Survival mode you have 5 different game modes, which all play different. 
Like a normal Survival mode (see how far you can get), Weapon Picker which playes like Gungame (you need to pick up new weapons constantly since you only have 1 magazine each). And even a mode in which you â€œtypeâ€ the enemies down.
            
The game has 30 different weapons and a ton of perks and power-ups, which allow you to customize your gameplay till a certain degree. (Whit each level up in a round you can choose between 3 to 6 random perks) 
          
[b][h1]Final Thoughts:[/h1][/b]
I really really enjoyed my time with Crimsonland. The game has a ton of different enemies, weapons, power ups and so on. The gameplay is smooth and it has enough different game modes and difficulties to not get boring at any time soon. And of course it also has high-score lists!
         
I can absolutely recommend Crimsonland to anyone who is even slightly interested in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035884174', 'num_games_owned': 804, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1516200776}
review:
[h1] Crimsonland; A cult classic, now better than ever [/h1]

The review turned out longer than I expected, so I will include a summary of my thoughts at the bottom.

Like a lot of people, I remember Crimsonland from back in the day. I first encountered it on a demo disk that came with a magazine I used to buy. With only the first chapter of the Quests mode being playable, I remember replaying it over and over again. Some years later, I discovered the Internet and what it had to offer, so I managed to obtain the full version of the game, finally being able to play through the entire thing. Rediscovering it again on Steam was quite a surprise, with a new look and a tempting price tag. However, having found out that perks are no longer present in the Quests mode, I decided against buying it. 

Forward a year later, and what do you know: Crimsonland is on sale, 80% off. Not only have the developers  re-added Perks into the Quests mode, but the game now comes with the classic version from 2003. It was a steal at the discounted price and I immediately bought it. 

A few weeks have passed since then and after playing through the game and going for some of the achievements, I'm happy to say that Crimsonland has not only retained everything that made it great (and a tiny bit frustrating at times), but has also managed to slightly improve upon it with a couple of new weapons, perks and game modes.


[b] The game has two main game modes, Quests and Survival, both with their own gameplay elements. [/b]

Quests mode is separated into 6 chapters, each one having 10 levels. There is no story that follows these, but they're all thematically different from one another. They also have replay value as you unlock difficulty levels and achievements. 
You start each level with a pistol, and pick up different weapons and powerups as the level goes on. You can't however switch between weapons you've picked up, but are instead stuck with the last one you did. Kills earn you XP which can be used to select perks that can help you through the current level, as they reset at the end of each one. Beating a level will unlock a new Survival game mode, weapon or perk. Everything you unlock will then be present in Survival mode, as well as future Quests levels.

Speaking of the Survival mode, it is devided into 6 other modes, each with its own set of rules. For example, Blitz is just like Survival, but sped up, with an increased number of monsters and powerups. Nukefism on the other hand has leveling and weapons disabled, allowing you to only use powerups if you want to survive. 

All  game modes provide a good challenge. The powerups and perks feel usefull and make a notable difference. Some weapons may seem underpowered, but each has its benefits in a specific situation. However, the randomess of it all, accompanied by some difficulty spikes may give the feeling that the game relies more on luck rather than on skill.

Even though all of the game modes are playable co-op with up to three other players, and each survival mode having its own leaderboard, there is no online play.


[b] The sound and graphics present the game well, but are lacking in some departments.[/b]

The game has a very clean look to it, so you'll be able to tell whats happening at any given time. Over a hundred monsters can be on the screen, with particles from your weapons, perks and powerups flying all over the place, the bits and blood of the monsters you killed clearly visible on the terrain for the remainder of the level. All this while the game manages to run smoothly all the way through.

Although the graphical update of the new version boasts plenty of advantages, I feel as the developers didn't go as far as they could in some places while, at the same time, toning down the visual noise in others. For example, the only purpose for the maps you battle on may be to provide a mere background for all the carnage, but they could have greatly benefited from a bit more detail, adding to the game's atmosphere. It's something I feel worked better in the classic version, as it had grittier visuals and a less vibrant color palette. 

On the contrary, all of the weapons still share the same model, which is something worth changing that, unfortunately, carries over from the classic version. I also consider the look of the menus in the classic version superior to those in this one, which look bland and generic, as if they were ripped straight out of a mobile game.  

The soundtrack isn't that memorable for the most part, but some of the songs, like the menu theme, are great at setting the tone and exciting enough to not get repetitive.  
As an added bonus, the soundtrack also comes separate from the game so you can listen to it at your leisure.


[b] In conclusion: [/b] 

Despite some slight missteps and wasted opportunities in remastering the visuals, Crimsonland retains its best qualities and adds onto them with new game modes, weapons and perks. It still looks and sounds good, while running and playing out with no issues. Some difficulty spikes and randomness in weapon drops and perk selection can make certain levels frustrating, but other than that the game is a blast to play and tempts you into getting all of the achievements. You can play co-op with up to 3 other people locally, as opposed to just 2 in the classic version.
There are leaderboards for the Survival portion, but the game lacks online multiplayer. Thankfully. 10tons has announced that they are currently working on three new top down shooters, so we can hope that Crimsonland 2 is one of them. 

The time for a sequel is high, just as the score and the recommendation. 

[b] I rate Crimsonland a 7/10 [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198042460330', 'num_games_owned': 2704, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1453, 'last_played': 1521426360}
review:
I am 100% about this game...

... Which is ironic because I really wasn't sure if I'd like it or not. I'm pretty positive that I got this from a bundle of some sort (HumbleBundle, I'm looking at you), and so kind of tossed it in my never ending backlog pile. It was buried so deeply, in fact, that I can't even tell you how long ago I added it to my library. 

What I can tell you is not playing this game sooner was a total mistake. Although Crimsonland might look like your stereotypical top down shooter, it's far from it. 10tons LTD puts their own spin on Doom-inspired mechanics and themes, and really takes the top-down genre to a whole new level. Sure, Crimsonland might not be the most graphically impressive game, but trust me - this literally does not matter whatsoever. The mechanics of the game run as smoothly as a hooker covered in lube. Or blood. Or something ( Í¡Â° ÍœÊ– Í¡Â°)

The basis of the game is simple - you start with a pistol (and yes, it totally packs a punch!), and in the early levels you encounter only handfuls of enemies. As you play, powerups and different guns are dropped (which, by the way, you unlock a wide variety of new ones as you play through levels). I'm not going to lie - the powerups in this game are absolutely amazing, and range from freezing enemies in ice to freezing time. A certain amount of tactical prowess has to be applied to each different level, as this isn't any simple top down bullet hell.

Last but not least, the game modes must be mentioned. There's a "quest" mode in which you unlock all the available powerups, guns, etc. Annnnnd then there's the "survival" modes, which offer a bunch of different and unique flavors of the game. Amongst these are a typing mode, an actual survival mode, a powerup-only mode, an AK-47 only mode, and a limited ammo mode, as well as a la mode. Wait, no, I lied about the last one. That's for pie and ice cream or something :D

Gory, gritty, and intense, Crimsonland draws you in with its fast pace, delicious mechanics, and lots of zombies. If you enjoy top down shooters and don't own Crimsonland, you should. If you do own Crimsonland, then stop hesitating. It's worth the time investment, I promise.

review:
If you have never played this game, then it could be fun.

-HOWEVER-

If you liked the original, DO NOT BUY THIS!  They changed the most important perk of the old game to make it work for the consoles, and it completely ruined the game for me and a lot of other people as well.  If you felt that telekinesis made the chaos of the long survival runs fun and like no other topdown shooter, you will hate this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979916483', 'num_games_owned': 1193, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 361, 'last_played': 1537670209}
review: One of the best top down shooters I've played - and it's been around for a looong time. I remember playing this around 2006 and loving it. It's crazy that it's still being updated! The survival mode is a blast, trying to get a higher survived time, and picking the right perks/weapon is a fun challenge. I recommend it, especially at the $2.79 price!

author: {'steamid': '76561198019320463', 'num_games_owned': 835, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1216, 'last_played': 1546473636}
review: I played this game for the first time when I was 16. Now I'm 32 and I'm still loving it :) It's a great arcade to play from time to time, so polished (it's been remastered) and funny if you have little time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977892146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1428532233}
review:
Exactly what it looks like in the vid. It's the most classic top-down shooter ever, and if you ever just want to blast some mosters for a bit this is for you.

It's an easy to approach, super fun, replayable game. Simplicity serves this game well: Shoot monsters, get many different weapons, level up and get many different perks, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015962014', 'num_games_owned': 1196, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1577576398}
review:
I remember playing the original version when I was 10 years younger, maybe even younger. Local Coop was also great for playing with friends.

They remastered the game and I must say, they did a great job too. Do yourself a favour and buy it. You won't regret it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042019586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1899, 'last_played': 1697377463}
review:
It's one in the morning.

I am wrecked on weed and burning through blitz mode with a zero-reload pulsegun with angry reloader, hot blooded, and an upgrade weapon buff. so every .1th of a second I'm blasting out with great balls of fire, plasma and err 'pulse' that chew through the zombie, alien, and spider minion hordes like chain guns until the ground beneath my feet is barely recognizeable through the blood, gore, bodies, and frozen chunks of dead bad guy all around me in my desperate last stand.

This is the best the game has ever been and I give it full marks. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971222470', 'num_games_owned': 2185, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1488501267}
review:
Great refresh of a great game from developer 10tons. Originally released in 2003, If you're looking for a classic arcade style top-down twin-stick shooter, Crimsonland is the game for you. Very fun to play on local co-op (up to 4 players) or by yourself. Controls and the concept are simple enough to get the hang of, great amount of content and replayability as well. 

If you like your games to start slow and easy and to end challenging and hectic then scoop up this big bad top-down shooting extravaganza!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005283699', 'num_games_owned': 1001, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 627, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 562, 'last_played': 1508204572}
review:
This is my all time favorite twin-stick shooter! I have played the original back in 2003 (which is included) as well as the re-release.

There are several game modes, the main mode is called Quest Mode and it offers 3 difficulties. You are placed in the middle of the map while enemies are storming at you in waves and you have to defend yourself from a top down perspective. Weapons (shotguns, rocket launchers, plasma rifles and many more) and powerups (for example bullet time, fire bullets, shields) are randomly dropped by dead enemies. While you shoot your opponents you will gain experience points and level up. Those levels offer special perks you can pick and they range from faster reload times to poison bullets. Each stage in Quest Mode has a distinct layout and starting weapon and by completing them you unlock new perks and weapons. The more you progress the more difficult the stages become.

Of course there is a Survival Mode, where you have to survive as long as you can as waves of enemies come after you. It features all perks and weapons that have been unlocked in Quest Mode. Or you try the Typâ€™oâ€™Shooter or Rush mode. The game also offers local multiplayer of two players on the original and up to 4 on the re-release.

Crimsonland's Quest Mode and multiple side modes offer enough content to have you entertained for hours. Each round feels different, depending on the perks you pick and the random weapon drops. I tend to play the game in short bursts, you can easily drop in and out. It controls fine with both mouse and keyboard or gamepad. Tech-wise Crimsonland only shows age in terms of graphic options, the overall look and mechanics have aged well.

The price tag is a bit high, but it's not spectacular overpriced. If you like action games with light RPG mechanics, give this one a go!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035826801', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 643, 'playtime_forever': 1003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1003, 'last_played': 1487293302}
review:
Played through normal mode + no scratch in about 4 hours, playing the game on side of another game.

Pros:

+ Solo gameplay is quite fun. Fun to see how far you can get and a lot of weapons to choose from.
+ Many perks to choose from whenever you gain levels in a map.
+ KB + Mouse works well.
+ 3 Difficulties to choose from + extra game modes after beating normal mode.
+ Bunch of anchievements to unlock.

Cons: 

- You will need good RNG to get through Chapter 2 Stage 10, c4s10, c5s6 and c6s10 without taking damage (for achievement + star rating) if playing alone.
- Would have liked to see better weapon balance. No point in using a movement speed slowing inaccurate minigun when you can use any shotgun to clear much more.
- Levels are pretty simple in design. Some levels with walls (or whatever) would be nice.
- You can't see where enemies spawn and they can spawn under you, making you take damage.
- Sometimes the enemy is just too overwhelming even if not going for star rating.
- All but the typing minigame feel unbalanced - enemies overwhelm you too easily most of the time.

7.5/10

review:
Juego de oleadas y mata mata sin mÃ¡s complicaciÃ³n que machacar bichos, que tan alegremente corren hacia nosotros, para llenar el suelo de pulpa de bicho retozÃ³n y alguna que otra casquerÃ­a mÃ¡s.

Agilidad en los dedos y una falta de interÃ©s por la salud del botÃ³n izquierdo del ratÃ³n, son los Ãºnicos requisitos que nos va a pedir el juego para ir resistiendo oleada tras oleada, bicho tras bicho. 

AsÃ­ de simple, asÃ­ de sencillo. 

El presupuesto para el juego se lo tuvieron que gastar la primera semana en whisky y muchachas ligeritas de ropa porque lo que es en los escenarios o en la variedad de los bichejos desde luego que no . Escenarios vacÃ­os y de cartÃ³n piedra que se combinan con oleadas que sospechosamente se parecen mucho a la anterior nos van a acompaÃ±ar a lo largo del juego, asÃ­ que apaÃ±ados vamos. 

Claro que no nos olvidemos que esto va de lo que va. AquÃ­ no hay trama, ni personajes, ni situaciones... solo disparar, esquivar y decorar el suelo con los sesos de los enemigos. 

Pero si bien es cierto que se echa de menos mÃ¡s variedad en lo escenarios y las misiones, al menos el juego lo compensa con los diferentes modos de juego, muy variados y divertidos. Un acierto que alarga la vida del juego mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de las misiones principales.

Para acabar, decir que este es el tÃ­pico juego que viene bien para esos ratillos muertos que no queremos complicarnos la vida con nada. Si lo juegas bien, porque entretiene y se deja jugar, pero si no lo juegas... pues bien tambiÃ©n, tampoco es que te vayas a perder gran cosa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013317980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1515116378}
review:
Crimsonland surprised me with how much fun it actually is.  It is an incredibly simple game in terms of gameplay. Simplicity is a double edged sword, it can be a great element or a terrible one, it all depends on the execution.

Crimsonland is  a twin-stick style top down shooter.  You spawn in a square map, enemies appear from all over and you must kill them all or die.  Simple as that.  There is more added in the form of unlockable weapons, â€œlevelingâ€, power-ups/drops, and perks.  During each round you kill enemies, gain experience, level up, defeat all enemies, rinse and repeat.  Each time you level you can choose a perk.  Playing the â€œquestâ€ missions steadily unlocks additional weapons and perks.  Both the weapons and perks are enjoyable and are a meaningful reward for the completion of a level.  There is enjoyment to be had from trying out each new weapon and perk.  Additionally during combat power ups will drop, these are things like temporary shields, health packs, temporary fire/damage boosts, speed boosts, etc. The perks do not carry over from level to level, which I kind of understand.  I think eventually if they did carry over youâ€™d be far too OP.  The drawback is that it can be a bit jarring to go from a level where youâ€™re powered up (and much faster than normal) to suddenly back to zero.  I died a few times on some levels readjusting.  Itâ€™s not a major problem by any means, and was the only real issue I have with the game.

Although Crimsonland is ostensibly a generic and basic game, the extra touches in the form of tons of weapons and perks elevate this game above itâ€™s generic base. I highly recommend Crimsonland. Itâ€™s a great deal of fun. I would however recommend waiting for a sale. Not to disrespect the devs (in saying theyâ€™re hard work isnâ€™t worthwhile) but $13.99USD is far too high a price. Pop Crimsonland on your wishlist and wait until itâ€™s $5USD or less. Crimsonland is great, and worth a purchase, just not at itâ€™s normal asking price. Good luck, may all your games never crash. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198145871719', 'num_games_owned': 7999, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 295, 'last_played': 1520185746}
review:
[h1]Impression[/h1]

If you like twin-stick or arcade shooters, Crimsonland is one you'll want to check out. Lately, I've been on a shooter gaming kick, but FPS are not generally for me, and permadeath is also a feature that I tend to avoid. Crimsonland is a top-down shooter with responsive controls, full controller support, and the ability to begin or resume the game where you left off.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The game consists of 5 levels, each with numerous "quests" that serve more like levels than quests. The [b]graphics[/b] and [b]soundtrack[/b] have a more [i]retro[/i] feel to them, and while appropriately understated, these really weren't the aspects of the game that impressed me. It was the gameplay itself that kept me playing all the way to the end.

To start with, you have multiple difficulty levels, which make it a great game for casual gamers and also for hardcore gamers looking for a "tough-as-nails" challenge.  For a casual gamer like me, normal difficulty can be completed in 4 hours or less. During the game, a certain number of achievements are unlocked through gameplay, but it also includes [b]achievements[/b] that are unlocked on greater difficulties, such as those for unlocking all perks, accuracy, or not taking damage. So, if you're a maniac achievement hunter looking for a real challenge, this game may be intriguing for you.

There are a wide variety of weapon drops, power-ups, and perks that keep the game fun and make each playthrough unique. There are also many different monsters to kill, each with its own characteristics. In addition, there is a local co-op feature which makes it possible to game with friends.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

I enjoyed it very much and would definitely recommend it to gamers looking for a similar experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984085729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 16258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 5, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1711204352}
review: Crimsonland is a timeless game.  I've been playing it since the original 2003 release and have thoroughly enjoyed the 2014 update.   The moving/shooting dynamics change with every weapon and every level as you add perks to your character.  Exploring this dynamic has been fun and compelling for over a decade.  I am showing no signs of getting tired of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061120433', 'num_games_owned': 283, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 18943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9158, 'last_played': 1690897809}
review:
I remember when I was 8 years old and I won my first computer, my father bought a small cd with ''100 games inside'' was one of the happiest days of my life, but a game caught my attention more Than all others... Crimsonland v1.3.0, the description said: Defend yourself from bloodstains with a spectacular nuclear weaponry, so yes I thought, I'll give it a try, when I double-clicked the crimson.exe A creepy song started playing on the loading screen, the last thing I remember was almost to have been paralyzed from so much fear of that song in the loading screen and in the scoreboard too, my dad and me spend HOURS AND HOURS AND HOURS, day after day playing this! we were disputing which of us would get the highest score!, we gathered such good memories with this game and I only have to thank each one of you guys at 10Tons for never giving up this game and always improving it and always adding content during all this time, I wish you all success to all the games you produce from now on!

Question: 
(1) The music that I was referring to in the text above was one called ''survo41'' and it was from the version v130 (made in 2002) in the sounds folder, and I've never heard of it in the newer versions of the game, was there any reason why it was not added to the final product?

(2) Do you guys intend to make any extra content for this game in the future? Or something that explains the history and the cause of these soldiers being in that fucked up hellhole full of aliens?

(3) Who the hell has the idea of making the Broodmother have a protective shield and the ability to bite you while she is protected?

Anyway... thanks again for this game, you guys rock!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066310618', 'num_games_owned': 3195, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 2167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1895, 'last_played': 1489800844}
review:
#####
35.3 hours playtime as of release of review. 
This review is for game version 1.2.0, and may not accurately reflect the current state of the game.
#####

[h1] [b]Overview[/b] [/h1]

Crimsonland is an action-packed top-down twin-stick shoot-em-up. You, a single human (or more if playing co-op, which is even more fun),  must face off against thousands of bloodthirsty enemies at once. With the aid of game-changing perks and screen-shaking weapons, you will conquer the levels, only to do it all again on the next difficulty up. And after that, there's an impressive variety of unique survival modes to hone your skills. Crimsonland is one of those games where a level may take 5 minutes, but a gaming sessions last hours.

[h1][b] Components[/b] [/h1]

[b]Visuals[/b] - Crimsonland 2014 (which has been updated so it's now a 2016 version) is an impressive overhaul of the freeware game Crimsonland. The graphics are scrumptiously HD and there's delicious new graphical effects. Killing the hordes of the enemies results in juicy crimson splatters, which permanently stain the environment. The permanent splatter and corpses allow for an incredible aftermath experience that most games can't even fathom. The glowing plasma is splendid and the ion weapons are stunning. The glows and explosions and colourful effects all add up to make a visually pleasing experience. Amidst all the effects, the actual graphics quality though is fairly mediocre to today's gaming standards. The background environments are vast but bare and bland, and the enemies are uninspired and indistinctive. The visuals of Crimsonland play a vital role for the action, providing a colourful experience, but still lacks in quality.

[b]Audio[/b] - The audio in Crimsonland is awesome. As soon as you start the game, you're greeted with the rock (I don't know genres, but I'm sure it's rock) music in the main-menu. The music is intense and gets the blood pumping, puting you in the mood for the massive hectic slaughtering of the impending onslaught. The sound effects provie solid feedback, from the gunshots to the projectile impacts. All guns sound unique, which makes them all stand out. However, the explosions lack proper oomf and the avatar's death sound is hilarious. Enemy deaths are appropriately satisfying and do a good job of letting you know you've killed your foe. Overral, the audio aspect of Crimsonland is pretty good.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - Crimsonland is gameplay-centric. There are many different guns ranging from blowtorches and shotguns to plasma miniguns and missile swarmers. Bonuses drop during gameplay, and these temporarily buff you with speed or fire bullets among others. Beating levels in the campaign unlocks perks and weapons which can drop in any game mode. Contrary to the store page description, there is actually 6 survival modes (the Typoshooter gamemode added in version 1.1.0). Having 6 different forms of survival really improves this game's longevity. However, the classic survival mode is probably the one you will play the most. Crimsonland also includes global leaderboards so you can show off your skills (or your hacks) to the world. This game's massive variety of survival modes is really awesome, and more games should follow in the vein of Crimsonland for this aspect. Survival mode is arguably the prominant feature of Crimsonland, however I believe the campaign is the best bit. The manually crafted levels offer unique scenarios for you to battle through, but even the same level will be a unique experience for different plathroughs. This is due to randomized weapon and bonus drops, and the almighty perk system. Kill enough enemies and you get to pick from 3 perks. They can improve and massively alter the gameplay but they only last for that level. Perks range from standard fire rate increase and reloading time speed, to bearing a contagious disease that slowly kills off enemies. You can get multiple perks per level and there's a massive amount of perks that allow for unique game experiences. Some perks are even multi-tiered, so that means you can get a seperate perk that improves a previous perk. The amount of perks and perk combos means you will be always experiencing new and exciting gameplay styles. Overral, the gameplay of Crimsonland is hell of a lot of fun, and local co-op opens up opportunities for even more fun!

[b]Story[/b] - N/a

[b]Functionality[/b] - Crimsonland has a couple of graphical settings and minimal options. This game is highly optimized and runs very smoothly even with thousands of enemies on screen at once. I am glad to see this game still receive attention even after its initial release in 2014. Overral, Crimsonland is a perfectly functional game.

[h1][b] Pros[/b] [/h1]
[list]
[*] Perk system allows for unique and interesting combos and abilites
[*] A fully fleshed out campaign that can last 20+ hours (especially if you try to beat every level on the hardest difficulty without a scratch, which I succeeded in eventually)
[*] 6 unique survival game modes, like the typoshooter where you are required to type the specified words to kill enemies.
[*] Stunning visual effects
[*] Sound effects for every moment in the game, plus some nice rocking music.
[*] Hectic action
[/list]
[h1][b] Cons[/b] [/h1]
[list]
[*] Mediocre graphics
[*] Fairly repetitive
[*] Nothing truly innovative
[*] Flat, bland environments
[*] Most enemies are identical or similar in behaviour
[/list]
[h1] [b]Conclusion[/b] [/h1]

If you're looking for crazy top-down shooter that you can play with your friends, then I highly suggest Crimsonland. This game will give you plently of fun and offers many gamemodes for different playstyles.
I give Crimsonland a 6.5/10, great hectic fun, but offers nothing substantial or innovative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198334370705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1686, 'last_played': 1524237167}
review:
At first glance, a simple game; but it has depth to it. Some might argue that the fact that there are clearly "better" weapons/perks , yet the game gives them randomly, dumbs down the game since they have trouble strategizing. These people are wusses and noobs... the above stated makes you think how you'll manage with suboptimal gear, this what adds the depth to this game.

The simplistic graphics actually help, as they dont distract and one can plainly see what happens at all times. And it still is satisfying to see an arena filled with body parts and blood (crimson blood).

The sound makes the weapons very fun to use; and the excellent metal/rock music fits the game perfectly.

Moreover, the game has a plathora of modes to make the game highly replayble (alone and with friends).

I've played the original game for more than I am willing to admit, and this game has a nostalgic factor for me.

This game isn't for everyone, but if you like twin stick arena shooters; it is worth trying.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061632923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1708299937}
review: Cool casual shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994009488', 'num_games_owned': 1072, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1306, 'last_played': 1644130563}
review:
This game brings back memories. The update UI works well, even if you rage a little inside every time you don't get the upgrades you want. The addition of a temporary sheild when you level up is the only way you can beat every level on perfect, and it will always be up to the RNG gods for those perks and upgrades to line up to get that gold star.

Once you beat the game, there is not much reason to keep playing, but to perfect all the levels, you'll be playing for at least 20 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141012453', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 51402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1081, 'playtime_at_review': 11086, 'last_played': 1711725279}
review: insane topdown shooter, single or local coop with up to 4 players at once. action with hundreds of alien insects coming at you from all directions simultaniously. you're gonna need steel nerves, gamingskills up to a level that no man would ever think possible and eyes (or brains) that register every movement in a split second to survive this game. choose perks when you level up, plenty of weapons to shoot with in categories from shitty to awesome. the longer you manage to stay alive the faster the aliens will come at you. great enemy AI will challence you to the max. btw it's kinda addictive too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049881896', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2138, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1657510229}
review:
Infinite ammo(except for certain game-mode), screen-full of targets (not from the beginning)
Varies weapon fits many style: 
AK, uzi, minigun, shotgunS for...well everyday use.
Explosives: RPG, rockets, small homing missiles, minigun or shotgun style of rockets or homing missiles...Good stuff.
Plasma weapons, Ion weapons, Gauss rifles, and you can guess: the shotgun or minigun version of them.
Also couple other goodies you have to try for yourself.

Also, random package to upgrade you momentarily; Leveling system to keep you alive in one run with upgrades (Mostly on you not the weapon though.)

I personally prefer the old version I had ...for about 15 yrs?

Well it's classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974516231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 108415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 10, 'playtime_at_review': 25274, 'last_played': 1711554616}
review: This game is so in touch with the realities of my everyday life...it's my "Sims", you could say. Alone, I am beset on all sides...not by evil, as some claim, but by things that just view me as a food source...and they don't care about my well-being in the slightest. The comparison to how Americans treat each other is inevitable. Overall, I find Crimsonland to be highly cathartic. I use it for meditation; it assists in finding my Beta state in much the same way as the Lotus position helps yoga pratitioners. Play this game. It will change your life, forever, for the better.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988271944', 'num_games_owned': 1346, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 535, 'last_played': 1479372788}
review:
Crimsonland Ã¨ un top down shooter in cui dovrete sopravvivere il piÃ¹ possibile  o completare le varie ondate di mostri (a seconda della modalitÃ  scelta).

In generale Ã¨ un gioco che crea dipendenza; semplice inizialmente, difficile quando si arriva piÃ¹ in alto, con un alto livello di sfida e il motivo non sta nella difficoltÃ  in se, ma in altro e lo andrÃ² a scrivere dopo.
Una grande varieta di armi e di abilitÃ  e varie modalitÃ  di gioco, non tanto differenti fra loro ma vi intratterranno comunque per abbastanza tempo.
PossibilitÃ  di giocare in Coop in locale; peccato, un piccolo online coop non avrebbe guastato.

La grafica non Ã¨ miracolosa, ma non ci si aspetta un granchÃ¨ da un top shooter poichÃ¨ le qualitÃ  da valutare sono altre.
La colonna sonora Ã¨ molto monotona; avrei aggiunto un pÃ² di tracce.

Come giÃ  detto in precedenza, Ã¨ un gioco che puÃ² creare dipendenza: Solo un altro livello e poi spengo (sehhh) e devo dire che sono rimasto sorpreso poichÃ¨ non Ã¨ un gioco di chissÃ  quale caratura e qualitÃ , tuttavia fa il suo dovere: intrattenere il giocatore.

Il vero lato negativo di questo gioco Ã¨ che il drop delle armi durante i livello Ã¨ realmente troppo casuale, spesso e volentieri ci ritroveremo con armi brutte che non centrano nulla con il livello in cui ci troviamo e oltretutto il gap fra alcune armi rispetto ad altre Ã¨ realmente  ASSURDO.

In generale, prodotto molto consigliato per passare un pÃ² di tempo.
Voto 6,5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198208138240', 'num_games_owned': 59, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1235, 'last_played': 1592872182}
review: Es un juego bastante adictivo, no muy extenso en terminos de la campaÃ±a (3 dificultades de 6 capitulos cada uno, con 10 niveles cada episodio, con una duracion media de 3 mins) , pero que dan ganas de repetirla una y otra vez y ademas los otros modos de juego son alusinantes. Los logros no son precisamente dificiles de sacar, a excepcion de algunos (como el de Gembine, los que hayan intentado sacar todos los perks entenderan xD). En conclusion, es un juego que vale la pena comprar para pasar el rato ya que es muy entretenido y, como dije antes, muy adictivo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040884867', 'num_games_owned': 2433, 'num_reviews': 901, 'playtime_forever': 180, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1477782439}
review:
These kind of games are admittadly my guilty pleasure games. Yeah, they are fairly simple and dumb, but they are really fun.

[b]I do recommend [i]Crimsonland[/i], but if you don't already have [i]Neon Chrome[/i], just go get that instead/first.[/b] It's from the same devs and it's like they took [i]Crimsonland[/i] and built a roguelite around it. Totally addicting.

[i]Essentially, with [/i]Crimsonland[i], you are simply fighting off waves of enemies.[/i] There are tons of perks and powerups and guns and one-off weapons. It all feels really satisfying, and has good controller support. All the right options are there too. I was like 'I don't feel like holding the shoot button down anymore', and I went into options, and *boom* they had a solution for that problem.

[b]Do I think it's worth full price? Not so much.[/b] I finished the game on easy in less than four hours. I got my fill, and although there is still a bunch more content, it's starting to get pretty difficult. It was fun, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030751377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 4067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3221, 'last_played': 1496605653}
review:
First of All, if you ever played the old Crimsonland and even kind of like buy this game. The remake lost nothing of the past game but improved here and there. New modes, a much more fun typ-o-shooter, better graphics....

For all the newcomers, you like Zombie genre? Interested in Alliens who want to rip you apart? Haunted by Giant Spiders? Well you got 'em all in Crimsonland. In a top down look, you run around, shoot in every direction, get some bonuses, grab some weapons... 

Basicly this game ideal to blow some steam. I regularly open the game spend half an hour and forget about it for a week. Because my roommate had the top score in type-o-shooter I learned to type with 10 fingers. This is a game mode where you kill monsters coming at you by typing the text above the monsters. (Remember astrotit ;))

I bought the game because I spend so many hours in the old version. If you get it below 5$ buy it

author: {'steamid': '76561197982043332', 'num_games_owned': 1215, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1682402452}
review:
One of my favourite childhood gaming memories, when I found out this was on steam I wept with joy. 

Pro's
-Remake is faithfull to the original in terms of the (excelent) level design in quest mode and all the guns and perks are the same.
-I personally love the soundtrack, and the SFX such as gun sounds are excellent. 
-Gameplay is fun and challenge ramps up at a good pace. 

Con's
-Only one I could find really was that I prefer some of the older models of enemies. But the old version of the game is included so can't complain about the game at all. 

In short: One of the most underated top down shooters ever. GG.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966623972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 231, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 166, 'last_played': 1617635924}

As far as I can tell its the same game as the original, only the Visuals are now clunky and the controls sluggish.

The original was better but its included. I got it for a quid or so in the sale.

Its a fun game though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990474042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 796, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 716, 'last_played': 1500627797}
review: Top notch mindless fun, blasting a wide range of monsters with a ludicrous range of different guns. Lots of different modes to browse. Snappy and well worth it for the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198201846482', 'num_games_owned': 1416, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 212, 'last_played': 1475353690}
review: Crimsonland is an absolute adrenaline-fueled blast! With its intense top-down shooter gameplay, hordes of enemies, and an arsenal of satisfying weapons, it keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The fast-paced action, challenging levels, and addictive survival mode make it a perfect choice for fans of old-school arcade shooters. The variety of power-ups and perks adds a strategic layer to the chaos, keeping you engaged and craving for more. Get ready to unleash mayhem upon countless enemies in a non-stop frenzy of bullets and explosions. Crimsonland is pure, unadulterated fun that will keep you coming back for one more round.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038743618', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 2030, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1404, 'last_played': 1486179273}
review:
This is just really a fun gem of a game. A nice stress reliever. I wouldn't pay more than $10 for the game because it will never be talked about for it's great writing, social commentary, nor will it be an insane competitve play game or a good game to bond with by playing co-op. 
But it's a nice break inbetween other games. It's nice to play a few rounds of survival or rush before heading to bed or into work.
 I keep it installed for when i want to play it. Sometimes I go months between plays, other times ill do hours in a single day. It's a good game to pick up and set down at any time.

The game itself is fairly straight forward from the trailer with 3 main modes (i think there's 1 more i don't play), story, survival, and rush (more extreme survivial). Use story to unlock weapons that will drop. There is a ranking board for score and the best part of the game is earning Perks which just help you kill more aliens and stay alive longer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972202337', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1571604747}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001905880', 'num_games_owned': 1193, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1474918748}
review:
In my last two (negative) reviews, I felt like I was endlessly banging on about repetitive gameplay. Thank you then, 10tons, for proving that repetition doesn't need to result in monotonous, stale gameplay. Just monotonous, stale writing from me.

Crimsonland is a simple game. A topdown arcade shooter fending off hordes of enemies with all the old-school trimmings: weapon pickups, score modifiers, bonus powerups, and generally being pretty bloody difficult. I assumed that I'd pick it up for a few hours, get bored fairly swiftly and face a bit of a grind to reach the end of the game. Surprisingly, despite my general disdain for wave-based shooters and zombies, this didn't happen.

There are two chief game modes - Quest is the 'story' mode, with sixty missions varying in difficulty and enemy types, and the progression through the game felt fairly natural. It's worth saying that this mode DOES have perks; in all game modes, you unlock perks within each level as you gain experience via slaying and wanton destruction. In earlier versions of the game, they weren't present, but have since been patched in. The perks and weapons that you unlock are varied and random, which lends plenty of replayability to each mission. One run you might open up with a Gauss Shotgun and absolutely massacre the opposition, and the next you'll be sprinting away wielding your piddly Blowtorch. Add in different enemy types, three different difficulties and the added lure of completing each mission without being hit, and there's plenty of content there.

Survival Mode is the other chief enterprise, and other modes come under this banner too, as you unlock them. This is a true arcade experience - you're just out to live as long as you can, and take as many abominations as possible with you. It gets very difficult very quickly, and you'll need to be more than just a decent shot to survive. Strategically strafing around the compact map towards powerups is a must, otherwise you'll be cornered and devoured before you know it.

Ultimately, the visceral gameplay is what underpins everything, glues it together. The visuals and audio are bland, dull, functional; the story nonexistent,  But it's damn fun to use all the different weapons, to repeatedly (but not mindlessly) butcher wave after wave of meatbags. I found myself wanting to come back to play a few more rounds, just for the satisfying feedback I got from using the weapons - I feel like the sound effects must have played a decent role in this.

It isn't perfect, and it won't be for everyone, but Crimsonland is as fun as hell. Hardcore and Grim difficulties await you beyond the main quest, and you even get the original Crimsonland (dated, but still fun) to boot. Pick it up at 75% off or better, and you're golden.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045765418', 'num_games_owned': 2112, 'num_reviews': 775, 'playtime_forever': 397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1474909970}
review: Crimsonland have like 60-stages campaign, stages that are repetitive, but not mindlessly. Cruising through each almost identical looking level are teaches you the finer points of Crimsonland's brutal risk and reward centric combat, which can in turn be parlayed into its many score based challenges. At the end of each level, you'll unlock a new perk or weapon that can be used while chasing high scores on the leaderboards. You might want to jump right to the leaderboards from the word go, but that'd be a mistake. Everything you need to learn and earn rests in a campaign. This is awesome, since there's a reason to play everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969965024', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1652467380}
review:
I love twin stick shooters, but this one has a really annoying way of interrupting the action to let you pick from perks. Now perks are fine, and fun, but they continually interrupt the action, and in a game like this it is very jarring. For example you are shooting and moving and thinking "I'll get these guys up there, then I'll head up and left shooting down at..." and STOP, up pops a choice of perks, you pick one, it goes away and "where was I?". If they were less frequent it would be less annoying, but I've had them pop up seconds apart. 

Other than that it seems like a competent, but not great shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992583059', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1705558001}
review: Crimsonland! I went on a quest the other day looking for twin stick shooters and came across this and Neon Chrome, the latest game from the devs...this game absolutely satisfies the twin stick itch, controls are tight and the leveling-up system is quite good...I am having a good amount of fun with this title, and despite its age the gameplay cannot be beat...if you would like a good, polished, balanced twin stick title, this is it...

author: {'steamid': '76561198008632106', 'num_games_owned': 1226, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1473144675}
review:
Its not my kind of game, but if you want to kill endless waves it can be fun. 

You need to do quest mode. Without that you cant unlock survival mode. You unlock everything through quest mode including different survival modes, perks, and weapons. Some perks help, others dont. Its a twin stick shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988576863', 'num_games_owned': 547, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1617791518}
review:
2003 strikes back!
It's the same old known top-down-alien-shooter'esque massacre that I loved playing on my first PC. Therefore this has updated graphics (more cartoonish but got used to it after 4 hours of non-stop playing) and more game modes (type-o-shooter, before "Typing of the Dead" was made).
Loadsa perks, loadsa crazy-ass weapons (seriously, the obsession with rockets is enormous :D), loadsa blood, what else do you want? Maybe plug-in your favorite music (from Quake, for example) and you're all set!
It's time to kick some ass and chew bubble-gum! (c)

author: {'steamid': '76561198086702749', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 240, 'last_played': 1679360853}
review:
Nostalgia driven purchase. still as fun as the old game (y)

I'll just list out all the things that can be improved for future update (Played with Mac OSX) :

- the perk popup window that show up everytime player level up is really breaking the immersive. it's better to use right click to open perk window like the old game so people can upgrade the perk anytime without feeling forced to upgrade everytime player level up

- maybe it's better to put the powerup timer not in the cursor but in static place like in upper left of screen like the old game. it looks pretty but it's hard to follow the number because the cursor moving around so quickly

- the killer wave you get from when you level up, I don't remember if it exist in the old game, I think it's unnecessary and it's kinda ruined the level design of some level that need some strategic shooting . Like that one level which you get gauss gun as starter and the enemies are queueing linearly around you, they got killed by the level up wave and I can easily complete the level. I remember this was one of that hard level which you need precision because the enemy can one hit kill you

- please enable windowed mode

still love it nevertheless (y)

author: {'steamid': '76561198213532837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1495118983}
review: Think Doom,Gauntlet and Gain Ground blended together but in a good way and you have Crimson land

author: {'steamid': '76561198118005728', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 564, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1471753340}
review: Crimsonland is an awesome top-down shooter. There are multiple enemy types, including aliens, mutant lizards, spiders and zombies that attack and track you in various ways. Slaughter the endless hordes with a large variety of kicka$$ weapons and killer perks. Reminds me a little of my favorite top-down shooter Nation Red.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975028311', 'num_games_owned': 1097, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 183, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 183, 'last_played': 1471049345}
review:
It's not terrible, but not very good either and definitely not worth full price. I think the biggest issue is the lack of terrain and the way the questing mode is structured. It's not cool that you have to do the "normal" levels first because they are too easy and boring. It's a shame because gun variety and the sound design are on point. Shooting feels good, especially the way gun sounds and joy rumble works together. The music is kinda meh though. The optional old version is actually better, but that doesn't seem to work with modern gamepads and resolutions without external tools and it's not that good either to be worth the effort...
I thought this would be a good game to play while listening to podcasts, but in the end all it did was to sap my will with it's utter mediocrity.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976746071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 749, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1648479207}

author: {'steamid': '76561198078301029', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1481340493}
review: Great shooting game with little to think about. You kill. You die. No crappy stories. No crap to make me buy shoddy toys for my kids. Nothing to make care about stuff. Just fun. And some powerups....

author: {'steamid': '76561197990384367', 'num_games_owned': 139, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1497252378}
review:
Bellissimo sparatutto vecchia scuola. C'e la modalitÃ  missione, con la possibilitÃ  di attivare ulteriori modalitÃ  ultradifficili come ai bei vecchi tempi. Oppure la modalitÃ  sopravvivenza... con la tastiera! Puoi digitare le parole che vedi per sparare ai mostri ma non credre sia poi tanto facile... 
Tanto, tanto divertimento e tanti flashback ovviamente pensando al C=64 e a quando andavo in sala giochi. 
Consigliato a tutti perchÃ© tutti troveranno il loro livello. 
Attenzione: puÃ² creare dipendenza.

Ah, il lato negativo? E' un po' ripetitivo. Ma le tattiche variano a seconda del livello, dell'arma e della modalitÃ . Io non ci vedo poi molto di male nel mischiare cose "a ripetizione" se poi uno deve affinare le capacitÃ  per quello che importa: sopravvivere alle varie ondate. E allora non si guarda proprio alla varietÃ .

author: {'steamid': '76561198277247864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 2867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1011, 'last_played': 1632368760}
review: Great game and very thoughtful developers. All gaming glithes and balancing problems spotted before seems all get fixed and it is now nearly a perfect top-down shooting. The implementation of new version perks/power-ups update into the 2003 classic version is quite amazing. Well done 10tons.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031704328', 'num_games_owned': 1008, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1470259042}
review:
My Gameplay In A Nutshell:

First Few Waves: "Not sure if I'm gonna dig this one.."

Next Few Waves: "Okay I can get the hang of this."

20 Waves In: "Fucking spider peices of shit, get over here!"

50 Waves In: "TASTE MY URANIUM COATED BULLETS YOU MUTANT FUCKS!!!"

Well done. Very enjoyable. Addicting as hell. Recommended as a bit of a joyful time waster. 9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198074390848', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2380, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1727, 'last_played': 1608069221}
review:
This is as easy as fun.
No mind, no strategy, no....just mayhem and tons of bullets.
Quests are addictive and quite hard to complete, infinte survival modes are fun to play with a good replayability.
The only great drawback is the lack of multiplayer online (even on lan would be something...)

review:
Paint the ground red.

With murder.

Amazingtitle, it took a LONG TIME for it to reach steam, but it is totally worth all that wait for that. And it goes on bundles pretty often.

There are other titles similar to it, like the 3d  Nation Red, but this is the best of its type. 
There is also an android version, but honestly it controlls pretty badly with the virtual sticks. 
Also, a ps vita version, I have not tried that. I  should probably also get it there when it is on sale one day.

It is old. It is not particularly pretty, but damn if it is not satisfying to mow down the endless waves.
