author: {'steamid': '76561197983271717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1447615576}
review: This game is tons of fun. If you liked Dawn of War Last Stand mode and arcade shooters, this game is for you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198050495772', 'num_games_owned': 846, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 518, 'last_played': 1448481069}
review:
- Addictive gameplay.
- Lots of levels, weapons and game modes.
- Lots of Perks and powerups.
- Nice Top-down 2D graphics.
- Unique sounds and nice metal soundtracks.
- Up to 4 Player Local Coop.
- Runs without a single lag on my laptop which has a first generation integrated (Intel HD Graphics).
- Easy to play, hard to master.

It would have been better if there was an online Co-op option to connect anyone across the net, a base defense game mode would have been great too, and some extra maps to choose before we begin the survival game mode, but overall Crimsonland is a good and fun game.

I recommend this game to anyone who likes survival and top-down shooters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038310096', 'num_games_owned': 899, 'num_reviews': 218, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1414257048}
review:
Crimsonland.

Its old.
Its classic.
Its updated.


I remember as i played Crimsonland YEAAAAARRRSSSS ago but anyhow, this "version" doesnt play like the ones i played or remember. So its kind of a "UPDATED" version.

Still Crimsonland is a hardcore Arenashooter you can (now) play with 3 friends at one PC. It makes a lot of fun and the Difficult is also very nice, not unfair.

A must-have title for people who like hardcore gaming and even more for people who like arenashooter....or just for some childhood memories~

author: {'steamid': '76561197970802842', 'num_games_owned': 2887, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1516827546}
review:
Let's start with the most important thing. This IS FINALLY CRIMSONLAND.

I wrote a review of this game a year and a half ago about this game being a bad update of the original. It took them a while, but the developers have finally fixed my issues with the game, and so I can say, with 100% certainty, this is the game I wanted (and thought I was buying in the first place.) Great job, guys. This makes me happy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005896561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 241, 'last_played': 1413202235}
review:
Original Crimsonland (2004) is one of my most favourite games ever. But the Steam version is a serious step backwards. New graphics are not as pretty, new UI is bland and forgettable, and the worst crime of all - the Perks are gone from the quest mode. That's right, they only exist in Survival, which I know some people don't even play.

You would be much better suited by playing the original version 1.9.8.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966853942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1462744792}
review:
UPDATE 4/24/16: so the dev reached out to me (comments) and they tweaked things in such a way that you have more opportunity to get to power-ups on the harder difficulties and even the playing field a little bit, not nearly as dependent on RNG and luck while still being a huge challenge...i just played all the way through the Grim difficulty and feelsgoodman.jpg

that said, this game is freakishly addictive (even when i wasn't happy with it two years ago) and is highly recommended

author: {'steamid': '76561198132758732', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1521849813}
review:
UPDATE: The game now DOES feature the classic mode. Which in my opinion is the only mode you should play. I'll leave the review as is other than some rewording and change the negative to a positive since they DO allow you to play the classic version which is still super fun. 
However my opinion on modern mode still stands since after playing it recently again, not too much has been fixed. It still gets hard way too fast and doesn't let you really enjoy it too much. However thanks a lot to 10Tons for reaching out and attempting to fill the gap with the classic version.

The modern version of this game has a lot going for it...but not enough.


Lets start with the positives:

I love the updated graphics, the new perks, the more streamlined leveling system, the ability to have four players at once, and many other details about this reboot of the classic crimsonland. Killing enemies is as fun as ever and almost every weapon is great and feels good for different situations (except you blowtorch!) and has a legitimate strategy. Perks are incredibly important and add a deep aspect of thought to the game (Do I get regeneration to keep my health up or choose fast reloader so I can kill enemies more?) and the sheer addictive nature of the gameplay will keep you hooked. Its a solid title...or should be...

Which leads me to the negatives:

Outside of the story mode this game isn't really as fun as it used to be. They took out a lot of things that made it fun. In solo survival the average player can expect to get to level 8-9 if they get a decent weapon before being absolutely annihilated by the hordes of enemies. If you add friends to the mix the difficulty ramps up even more and you will be lucky if you clear level 6. Its almost a broken level of hard. Theres no fighting it. No matter which perks you pick or which weapons you have the survival mode reaches a certain point early on that just immediately kills you. 

Your choices feel useless and it becomes kind of a drag when you get the perfect weapon combo with the perfect perks and then you just get slaughtered anyways by the sudden wave of splitting spiders and zombie lords that surround you out of thin air instead of coming out of the sides of the screen like they used to. The previous version of crimsonland slowly spiked the difficulty more and more making the survival last longer. It really felt like you were, you know, surviving? 

This version of crimsonland has no such subtlety or flair. They let you gain a couple levels and then just murder you outright with a frustrating amount of enemies that are impossible to fight. Let me put it to you this way. I was the 3rd highest ranking player IN THE WORLD in the previous crimsonland but in this one I can barely top level 10 in solo survival. They have taken one of the greatest and most fun modes of the game and just smashed it and made it unplayable. If they had a difficulty choice I think it could mitigate this. This is the only game I think actually NEEDS an easy mode.

Another thing that is absolutely broken in this game is the enemy spawning system. In the previous crimsonland enemies came out of all 4 sides of the screen giving you a chance to plan ahead. You could see a horde of zombies and decide which way you want to bait them to try and get an opening to dive for that powerup or weapon. You can find the big monster that is spawning little ones and put that sucker down before he overwhelms you.

This crimsonland has destroyed that too. It is quite common now to have enemies spawn on top of you and immediately kill you. Nothing sucks worse than to be 10 minutes into a boss battle and to be killed by a horde of tiny red aliens spawning right on top of you. Or to be doing a survival round with your favorite weapon and perks and to have a lizard king spawn right next to you and one shot you instantly. Its painfully frustrating and can make you want to chuck your keyboard across the room. It has happened to me in almost every mission of this game and is the most common way to die. Some enemies still come out of the sides of the screen, but more than half of them just appear with a flash wherever they feel like regardless of how inconvient it is for you.

So in conclusion, the game is fun but ultimately frustrating and not worth your money. They could have had a solid remake of a fun arcade shooter on their hands but they've instead destroyed it by breaking the difficulty and spawning and made it virtually unplayable. If you do buy this game, you'll discover its fun palls rather quickly because of its major stumbling blocks. It is a shadow of its former self and if you want to play a fun arcade shooter, ONLY play the classic version of this game and ignore the inferior modern mode.

Play the classic mode. That part is fun, but skip the modern version. Its just not fun anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071810195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 17574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4381, 'last_played': 1620421345}
review:
I enjoy this style of game, so, overall, I've had fun with Crimsonland. However, there were some really badly missed opportunities with this game. For example, can somebody please explain why in the hell you earn buffs (faster reload, faster running speed, increased damage, increased xp gain, increased power-up drops etc.) if you can never activate any of them in the quest game mode. Who cares if you can use them in survival mode, I want to beat all the levels on every difficulty setting, but, quite frankly, without being able to use a buff or two, beating many of those levels once you get to Hardcore and beyond depends entirely on what your first weapon drop is. By the time a second weapon drops so many baddies have spawned that getting to a specific spot is next to impossible, you're just in full on kite mode. Not only that but your character moves slower than many of the enemies and is slowed briefly by taking damage, meaning one hit equals death in most cases because the brief pause allows the hoard to overtake you. Perfect time to activate the faster run buff you unlocked, but no, it's worthless. C'mon guys, with a few minor adjustments, this could be a real good time.

***WOOT!!! Thanks for putting the buffs in the quest mode. That was my one complaint. Also I really enjoy the type mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000943979', 'num_games_owned': 1029, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1529594511}
review:
I should start with a couple of things: 

1) I do recommend this game. But it's not a very strong recommendation. 
2) My decision to purchase was largely nostalgia-driven. 

Those two caveats disclosed, my review is relatively simple. This is a fun top-down shooter that is a bit stuck in the past. It's a game that for me, back in 2003, was a pretty big deal for something that today would fall into a much more competitive indie genre. The basic premise is: you're a guy, you run around in circles, you shoot things and they bleed. Eventually you're going to die, but along the way you can level up to gain perks which propels the arcadey gameplay.

The game is effectively untouched except in superficial, and relatively inconsequential ways. It really needs much more than that to be anything but a game people like me are willing to purchase because they have fond memories of playing. You can use modern resolutions now! The UI is updated (but it's bland)! But that's about it. Effectively, this is a PC game from 2003 ported to a PC platform of 2014.

The gameplay is still fun. But the asking price, and the lack of change and balance to the game over the course of a decade is unlikely to bring in much of an audience beyond people who played Crimsonland prior to its launch on Steam.

I wanted very much to see some new game modes, some new weapons, some new perks, some new something. But really, I have the same game on a new computer with a new UI. Pretty unimpressive.

On sale, this game is worth the time and money I think. Though it's very hard to make the case for something old that isn't doing much to take advantage of a huge sea change in what a game can be, and what the PC platform is able to do. I was happy to buy the game hoping against hope that maybe some additional content will be added, or Steam Workshop integration will come along. Though I doubt that is likely, and I doubt you'll feel as nicely as I do about this game, I think you can still have a good weekend's worth of fun if you give it a shot.

> Shoots it with a shotgun.

11/10.  Need more cans of Raid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050446493', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 312, 'last_played': 1420777270}
review: If you like twin stick shooters, I wholeheartedly reccomend this game. There are a ton of weapons to pick from (albeit some much better than others), perks that change up the gameplay, and 4 player local support. Although the quest mode is short (my first run-through took me about 2 and a half hours), it may as well be the tutorial as it introduces you to every enemy type over time and unlocks all of the weapons/perks for use in survival mode. My particular favorite mode is blitz, which is basically normal survial mode on fast forward.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996138531', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1706772609}
review: man... you guys gotta play this twin stick shooter (in the vain Robotron 2084 and Smash TV) sure, you see it now and think "it looks like another stupid mobile game" well when it came out, it was all the buzz in the freeware pc gaming community then made some more waves when it went to share ware. it's simple and nothing terribly special, but it's lots of fun, satisfying weapons, lots of power ups that keep wanting more just to see what else comes to attack you and how you can mow down hoards of enemies. it was one of my favorites as 13 year old and it was the first M rated game i ever played so i got mad respect for 10 Tons and Crimsonland will always have a place in my heart. a small place, but i can't deny it. it's fricken there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011435134', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1419916836}
review:
Changes from Original
- More weapons and Powerups to pick
- More game mode like Blitz or Nuke
- Grim Difficulty
- Normally perks disable in Story Mode but later you can customize by pause and type GRIM
- 4 Co-op players
- New Episode 6

Weakness
- Some issues has bugged like game crashed when started
- Monster Vision removed, let 3.4 Hidden Evil is almost impossible to No-Damage clear
- Friendly Fire cannot set in option, must customize by GRIM
- 1st quarter set of weapons is too useless when against final chapter but frequently dropped

Overall
    One of my best choices to play killing swarms of alien although leveling affects stage to stage (not like Alien Shooter Vengeance that leveling affects all game), it compensates by 4 Co-op players which isn't found in Alien Shooter and besides story and survival, more modes acquire by ending whole story, increase interesting such as Type'O'Shooter, Rush, Blitz, Weapon Picker and Nuke.

Suggestion
- Add internet co-op player mode for oversea playing
- Fix crash issue in Windows 8
- New original tunes
- Ion weapons need more improvements although they can be upgraded by Ion Master (Original one is powerful enough to fight in late chapters)

author: {'steamid': '76561198005143507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1498799406}
review: I was skeptical at first but it is more fun than I expected.  What it does, it does well.  It can be pretty difficult at times, but there is a pretty fun variety of weapons and they behave quite differently.  There is nothing more satisfying than picking up a power up and mowing down the enemy just as you were about to get overwhelmed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974653649', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 169, 'last_played': 1630148695}
review:
Played the demo of this game a loooooong time ago and had a blast.
It seems liked they updated it with higher res textures etc. The UI looks more slick now, but I think it was more gritty back then. I kinda liked that look so a small point I don't like.
The gameplay's fun, ton of weapons/perks to unluck and quite a few different game modes to unlock and enjoy.

TL;DR :
Tons of weapons, enemies and fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044081373', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 115, 'last_played': 1460064233}
review:
An HD remake of a lesser known gem; Crimsonland Classic (included with GOG version). Most of my review comes from the GOG (DRM-free) version of Crimsonland, so my Steam stats don't reflect my overall playtime with this game.

PROS:
+ Fun, twin-stick, arcade gameplay.
+ Easy to pick up, difficult to master.
+ RPG-like perks system.
+ Plays with both mouse & keyboard and Xinput (360) controllers.
+ Includes 2-4 player co-op.
+ LOW hardware requirements; a NETBOOK can run Crimsonland.
+ Mac and Linux versions are now included.

CONS:
- No online multiplayer...yet.
- Graphics snobs will take issue with Crimsonland's 1990s arcade style graphics.

Note:
Available DRM-free with Steam key on Humble Store (how I'd gotten the Steam version). GOG version is DRM-free and includes Crimsonland Classic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970329288', 'num_games_owned': 2788, 'num_reviews': 1451, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1446549688}
review:
A non-biased 2nd look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FwbfEPNCwkc

Playing this game brought back a flood of memories and I couldn't figure out why. Then glancing across my retail games collection I noticed the box.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=39PPl-nyTW4

Yes I still have the original retail 'boxed' version. This is one of the best top-down survival horde modes you can get. It never gets old. If you like old school top down, twin stick shooters like 'Robotron' you'll love this! - Awesome game... Enjoy!

author: {'steamid': '76561198032447372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 1493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1493, 'last_played': 1409394132}
review:
Basic idea of this 2D Arcade Top-Down Shooter, is, you run from baddies & shoot at them for as long as you can, then, they eat you alive.

You have good arsenal of weaponry at you disposal. Different mods of firearms, flamethrowers, plasma-ion-gauss toys, rocket launchers and some other weirdness. Most of them are quite playable and offer unique experience, but, some just really bad and get you killed very quickly :)

Enemies are not too diverse in form and even less then that in essence, but hey, they come in different colors !!! Nevertheless, while number of enemies will usually be your biggest concern, towards some of them you'll develop quite special feelings ...

And also there are powerups, popping-up all over the place. Not too important at first, but later, picking them up in right order (or just being lucky) is pretty much the only way to finish a campaign level.

Oh yeah, different play modes, campaign, survival, co-op and some other joyful ways to experience inevitable death ... Survival is arguably most interesting one, though, honestly, I've enjoyed it more in original game. Now, 6 to 7 perks per game is not too much to go by.

There isn't much to say about graphics or sounds (thanks god days when those were important are gone), but overall gameplay is awesome, game is addictive as hell !!!

Enjoy, don't forget to order a T-shirt ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198004391513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 5243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3293, 'last_played': 1414447805}
review:
I did play the original and I really like the fact that the game has been moved to HD format. I played a hell out of it and I think it is safe to say that story only begins after the campaign has been finished. Survival is addicting as it only can be.

Before you'll read the rest of the review please bare in mind, that I like this game, so don't get too negative image from upcoming sentences. It's just thera are some problems that will start bothering you after 15+ hours in the agme. If you don't intend to play that long, stop reading and just buy it, especially for local coop.
 
Unfortunately game tends to be a bit annoying. After a while, I know which guns and perks will work and which will not. Since it is all random it may (and it repeatedly will!) screw you over. I'd like to explore more exotic guns and perks combinations, but the game simpli will not let me - because it is all random.

In the end I was hoping for a little bit more - like a mode with a bit of control over gun drop, or mechanic (perk?) that would allow it. Also, I think there should be sandbox mode since a lot of perks are not well described and also a lot of stuff doesn't work together at all (e.g. rockets don't seem to apply the poison bullet effect).

Overall, I think the game is great, but longevity is crippled by lack of improvements compared to the original game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022292984', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3903, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1280, 'last_played': 1659361763}
review:
I've been playing Crimsonland pretty much since its original release, and it was a total time killer at the time. Obviously, I was quite hyped when I heard about the updated version on Steam. And I have to say that I am quite disappointed with it. 

The HD graphics are just... meh. Sure, it is in high resolution, and new level backgrounds look nice, but everything else looks like garbage from year 2000. Really, the old version just had better overall design. The new monster graphics are ugly, the weapon icons are beyond any recognition, and the new UI is not just ugly, but it is also less usable. It is virtually impossible to determine how much of your Shield is left when surrounded by enemies, and it is also very hard to determine the exact time left in reloading (why not just leave the clear and accurate "clock" from the old version?).

The game is now released on many platforms. Usually, there is nothing wrong with that, but for Crimsonland it meant that some content was removed because it was unusable on consoles. I really miss the Typ'o'Shooter mode, and some perks like Pyrokinetic and Evil Eyes. 
Speaking of perks: the new Telekinetic is just garbage. Instead of allowing you to hover the crosshair over the powerup and wait for a few seconds, ALL powerups are now gravitated towards you even when you really don't need that. Ever wanted to lose the game because a mysterious force made you pick up the Blowtorch? Well, now you can. Say thanks for consoles for one more butchered PC game.
I was also really disappointed by having perks disabled in Quests mode by default. Sure, one can say it is more challenging that way, but I've always perceived Quests as an extended tutorial for Survival mode, where player unlocks the perks and tries them out. Without the perks, the difficulty becomes just absurd on Grim, and the luck factor starts to account on your success way more that your skill. Why not just make an achievement for finishing the game without the perks? I believe that'd have been the best of both worlds for both hardcore and usual gamers. 

Some quite significant changes to the game balance were also made. And while I appreciate the new way Fire Bullets powerup works, I will never understand why rockets weapons are THAT powerful now, and why the almighty Splitter Gun is reduced to a useless garbage when compared to the old one. Still, the balance is better than it was in general, I think.

I really dislike new Survival mode. You can barely get 6-9 levels if you are really good (and lucky), and that really limits your chances of survival. The game session is also much shorter now, as monsters gain power and health much quicker than before. I miss the old epic 1+ hour battles.

Online highscores are implemented really well and provide a lot of additional info that helps to identify cheaters.

In conclusion, Crimsonland is still a fun game. Not as fun as the old version for me, but if you are new to Crimsonland - just wait for the sale and go grab it.

I was very glad, to see Crimsonland in STEAM. But I was dissappointed just after I had launched the game. Everything is different, from menu till animation of the monsters. The aliens are so different from original Crimsonland, that I just don't want to play this game.
Your hit points bar is not a bar anymore. Now, it's a... CIRCLE! A circle around your soldier! :facepalm:
Changes are so BIG that I'm already hate this game.
Those people, who haven't play the original game, may love this one. But all those, who had been playing Crimsonland earlier, won't like it. 
It's just my opinion. And I am very frustrated about what happened to the STEAM version of this GREAT game =(

review:

review:
Amazing game, but, no Online CO-OP? The progress is not sync with Steam? That SUCKS (if you play it from another PC, or, if you format your PC, you'll lost all your progress).

I recommend the game, but devs, you must change those things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056067731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1462, 'last_played': 1511146266}
review:
If you're looking for a top-down shooter, Crimsonland is your game of choice.

[u]Pros[/u]:
[list]
[+]Challenging
[+]Smart AI
[+]Replayability
[+]Good extras
[+]Decent variety of weapons
[+]Very fun when playing friends/a friend[/list]

[u]Cons[/u]:
[list]
[+]No story
[+]No armor
[+]No grenades
[+]Not able to use perks in quest mode[/list]

Would recommend to a friend, only if it is on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003352401', 'num_games_owned': 1224, 'num_reviews': 384, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1406025756}
review:
Le mode principal est soporifique au possible mais nÃ©cessaire pour sâ€™amuser en survie (puisque vous devrez auparavant dÃ©bloquer armes et perks). Le pire est que les 60 niveaux sont trÃ¨s mal Ã©quilibrÃ©s et que si vous nâ€™avez pas la chance de voir apparaÃ®tre telle ou telle arme vous serez bon pour recommencer le niveau ! Une seule arÃ¨ne (avec tout de mÃªme quelques variations de couleur), assez peu dâ€™ennemis diffÃ©rents et un personnage au dÃ©placement bien trop lent pour ce type de jeu, on pourrait penser que Crimsonland Ã©tait un Ã©chec total.

Pourtant, une fois les premiÃ¨res heures dâ€™ennui passÃ©es (ou les nombreuses pour les fous furieux qui voudraient boucler le mode principal dans les trois difficultÃ©s diffÃ©rentes), il faut bien avouer que les cinq modes survie sont variÃ©s et addictifs ! Le systÃ¨me de perks est rÃ©ellement amusant et permet de jouer encore et encore sans avoir lâ€™impression de faire deux fois de suite la mÃªme partie. Les armes sont trÃ¨s variÃ©es et le mode multi jusquâ€™Ã  quatre est gÃ©nial.

Au final, si vous avez la patience de vous ennuyer quelques heures avant de profiter pleinement dâ€™un jeu et que vous aimez les top down shooters, donnez-lui sa chance. Si vous ne correspondez pas Ã  la description prÃ©cÃ©dente vous pouvez passer votre chemin sans regret.

Rarely has a PC game given me arthritic pains like this one. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone with carpal tunnel but for everyone else 5/5. 

By the 4th chapter of the campaign you are killing roughly 200 things a minute.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960570626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2073, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1941, 'last_played': 1463492417}
review:
Old game that has been remade and brought back in 2014.
Never played the first one but picked this up after seeing a Giantbomb quicklook and can say that this game is addictive.
If you are after a easy to pickup game but take effort that can give you endless fun with survival trying to out do your own high score or beat your friends score then pick this up. There is a quest mode that prove challenging and you will no doubt get better the more you play learning the tactis against certain mob types.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970908031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1405097853}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001538160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 341, 'last_played': 1641644169}
review:
unfortunately not as good as the original. unlike the original, perks are not available in the questmode, unless you know the secret password "grim" to get to the secret options menu...WTF??? This is the lazy mans attempt on a newer version of Crimsonland, so the multiplayer is only local, which doesn't really work for most PC users.

For those wondering:
To unlock the secret options menu start a game and press Esc, then type "grim" and the menu will open.

review: Not the the exact classic I remember as you cannot redeem perks during mission playthroughs, but still a good simple game all around, 4 player local coop support (if using xbox 360 controllers, didn't seem to work with ps4 wired), new weapons and all the originals, haven't played far enough to see if it still has the typing survival game mode

review:
It's ok but... why?

Crimsonland was originally released in 2003. It's cool that it's getting re-worked and distributed on Steam, but srsly, 14 dollars for what amounts to a few new perks and a slight graphical update? Really?! I like that they added an online network mode, but I don't intend on ever playing this with someone else. They have actual games for that. I play this game to relax and kill time while listening to audiobooks. Crimsonland isn't a bad game, it's just... the same as it was in 2003, when so much of gaming has moved on. Risk of Rain and, to a lesser extent, Binding of Isaac feed the same high with much more content and better action, for less money. Maybe Crimsonland will update with some new content, but until then, I'm going to stop playing. Also, their unlock system is terrible.

Buy it if you have to to satisfy your nostalgia, I guess. Otherwise, wait until it's a humble bundle or less than $5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092161466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 697, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1527340733}
review: Awaited HD Steam remake of a classic top-down swarm shoot-em-up game. Action and mayhem of the original Crimsonland is captured satisfactory style. Though, UI and mouse controls lack in this version in terms of preference, the new 4-player local Co-op, as well as additional guns, perks and gamemodes really cheers things up. Simple and addictive gameplay makes this package original, fun and easy to get a hold on to. Any new players should experience the madness of Crimsonland!!

review:
i'm swmming in the pool of nostalgia and joy. old crimsonland fans will love this game, the few things that bothered me was:
-poor menu design
-perks cannot be used on quest mode, only on survival

i can bear with poor menu design but no perks on quest mode is ridicilous. please add at least a checkbox or option or something like that to enable perks in quest mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005858596', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 5469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1508, 'last_played': 1709955591}
review:
Fantastic game. Has come a long way since it was first released. A lot of guns have been balanced. The only shit ones are the plasma cannon (knocks enemies around too much and doesn't deal anywhere near enough damage) and the blowtorch (lol).

Very much so worth a buy at full price if you like classic twin-stick shooters. Even comes with the old 2003 version!

review: nice time and monster killer

author: {'steamid': '76561197993384059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1404310093}
review:
[h1]Basic Infos[/h1]
Gameplay lengh: 7 hours to finish the 120 main quests but otherwise as long as you want - It doesn't have a story, or even any purpose other than to rack up points during late game. It's much more of an arcade focused game akin to very early 90's arcade games of this kind.
Required skill level: medium
SPECIAL WARNING: As already shown in the screenshots on the storepage this game includes [i]Spiders[/i] and a lot of them in various sizes and shapes and from there it even get worse. You should refrain from playing this game if you suffer from arachnophobia.

[h1]About this game[/h1]
There we have it, the amazing game [i]Crimsonland[/i]. I still remember this game as a Freeware title in 2001 before it turned into shareware. And wow, the game inproved massively over the course of 13 years. This game was inspired by the, back then, famous game "Phobia II" in 1998, which in turn is very similar to the game [i]Threat[/i] in 1995 and [i]Smash TV[/i] in 1990, but Crimsonland made this subgenre of frantic top down shooting popular and very well deserved so. Unfortunatly I forgot about it after 2007 and thought it would never see the light of day again. Until recently...

So what is it all about? It's really simple to explain. You are a [b]Manly Space Marine[/b] with the important mission to kill various types of [i]Aliens[/i], [i]Zombies[/i] and [i]Bugs[/i]. It sounds like childish fun on paper and thats exactly what it is. It's called Crimsonland because you basically paint the ground blood-red from pulverizing anything that shows up on screen. That basically sums up everything you need to know.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The core gameplay for this game is very simple. You control a soldier from a very retro-esque top down perspective via the WASD layout and aim and shoot monsters for score. Sometimes, monsters drop power-ups, which you can choose to pick up, or not as you need to conserve them while they're on the ground in order to get the fullest potential out of any of them. Having a strategy on how to progress properly is essential in this game so besides blasting Aliens it requires some forsight and mental preperation of things to come. Often your chances of survival your way to the power-up itself so you can pick it up isn't even big as the ever coming monster waves keep you occupied otherwise.

Two of the basic main game modes are a [i]Quest mode[/i], which provides the Player with a set of "Missions" where the term only is used in the loosest of senses as the only thing you have to do in each mission is to kill a specific set of monsters until the bar of the upper side of the screen is filled out. It gets interesting however if you like to survive the round without taking a hit since the game at least acknowledges it so you can honor your skills with this game.

Being good at [b]Crimsonland[/b] gets rewarded with a star and an achievement for survivng all normal missions and this game has some of the most difficult to get achievements I've seen yet, apart from [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/65300/]Dustforce[/url]. As it requires a lot of partience to be rewarding, only the most hardcore of players may ever see one of the more difficult to get achievements. By completing missions you can unlock new Weapons, perks and Game Modes.

The other mode is something that gets unlocked during the first few missions and that is the [i]Survival Mode[/i]. Survival mode is the Flesh and Bones of this entire game as this is the game mode where you can get level ups to attain the perks you previously unlocked in the Quest Mode. There is a very well structured On-Line Scoreboard so if you feel competitive you can always try to reach the Top 100. 

[h1]Graphics and Sound[/h1]
To get straight to the point the graphics feel a little bit dated but I do believe that in this case it seem appropriate given the age of the game of it and how fluid the gameplay is. In terms of art direction I say that it all feels very pleasant to the eyes, as you can already tell from the pictures on the Steamstore for this game.

In terms of sound effects this game feels a little bit lackluster and is the worst thing this game has to offer regarding everything else [i]Crimsonland[/i] as to offer. Shooting your guns doesn't feel as strong as it should in my opinion and even launching a nuke doesn't feel as good as it should be. However I believe that the Music is pretty spot on given the gameplay as shooting up monsters and Metal seem to go hand in hand with carnage-themed games since Doom 1.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
I believe that this game is a fine example on how gameplay throughout the simplier ages of video game design [i](think about Smash TV or Robotron)[/i] can still be this refreshing. Sometimes you just want to shoot some monsters and rack up points with not much else. So if you believe that it's the game for you I hereby highly recommend that you should pick it up even if it isn't on a sale right now, as this is one of the genres finest.

[h1]Recommended food while playing[/h1]
The hottest Chili that you can find in order to fire yourself up for the madness that is this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971350945', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1405136059}
review:
Kudos to 10tons.com for Doing The Right Thing.

The original game required activation from their server. A few years ago, they shut that server down, meaning that you no longer had access to play the game you paid for.

Personally, I feel that if a company is going to shutdown hardware required to use purchased software, they should be required by law to provide a working solution, be it a patch to remove the dependency on the server, source/binary for the server, etc.

But in a sea of EAs, and Activisions, and Ubisofts, 10tons has decided to honor the purchases made. Well done.

This new version is mildly disappointing though.  Partially because I was wanting access to the old version I'd enjoyed before; this is a "remastered" version.  This version is shinier than the version from 2005, but if feels like the character has put on about 40 pounds since then.  The movement feels very sluggish compared to the orginal, but mostly its the inevitable "improvements to balance" that developers think they need to make in order to justify asking for more money.  Several key power ups have been drastically weakened making several stages that were near impossible before, now just not fun.

I like this game, because I liked the original, but if you've never played it, probably best to just move along.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993343821', 'num_games_owned': 927, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1632615788}
review:
Are you a fan of top down arena shooters? Then this game gives you a great bang for the buck.

The low price and high replayability makes it a really solid mini-game to pick up and play when you need a break from quest dialogue or crafting in <insert some other game>

I especially like the Survival mode where you gain xp and activate new perks that drastically change your playstyle. Said perks are unlocked through the story mode (by story, apparently they mean the name of the level can SOMETIMES be linked to the stuff you'll face in the level :p )

I have an xbox 360 controller plugged in and "hey presto" I can play local multiplayer with a friend (or 3)... Great fun :)

So yeah, if you have a few bucks/euros/quid burning a hole in your pocket, this could be the game for you :)

ps. my Bullguard antivirus was a bit silly and decided to quarantine the game.exe file, if that happens, just go into advanced settings of your antivirus and make an exception so your AV program doesnt freak out, its perfectly safe to play, or it wouldnt be on steam :) ... I hope :P

author: {'steamid': '76561197982454862', 'num_games_owned': 854, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1462, 'last_played': 1696535212}
review:
As a long time player of Crimsonland, I really love this game. I lost count of how many times I've beaten this game. I've received free steam key for by providing my previous purchase receipt. Thank you for that.

Now it is the time for hearth-breaking words

Steam version is not what I know as Crimsonland. Sure they preserved the game style, but messed up with too many things.
- Most of the screen is covered with gun / health / join 2nd player vs.. parts. 
- Most graphics changed to be "modern" which makes game look like a flash game. Old graphics were far better
- Perks removed from Quest mode. Why? It makes game too easy? Try handling a thousand of bad guys in hard mode.
- In the Survival mode you can use Perks, but you can not select when, it just pops up and removes from you the zone.
- Some most useful perks removed from game. Why? Is it too hard to not delete code lines?
- It does not support steam cloud, so my settings and level data is not synchronized between my computers.

Other than that, it is still fun. But if you really want to enjoy this game please buy old version if you can.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051418949', 'num_games_owned': 1605, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1709835449}
review:
Yep, it's Crimsonland.

Simple, brutal and to the point of mowing down tons of aliens, spiders, zombies and whatnot â€” or being brutally murdered by them. With lots of weapons and perks (like in fallout! we used to say) and both survival and quest modes.

I remember playing it back in high school, and boy was it fun! That classic version is apparently included now, but I'm fine with the remake to be honest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008012572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 4636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1489, 'last_played': 1510289422}
review:
Crimsonland only knows one trick, but it is a very good trick. You are... some guy with a gun, standing in the middle of a completely flat plain somewhere presumably not on Earth. You are surrounded by perpetually spawning monsters- aliens, zombies, giant spiders, giant beetles, giant spider that gradually split up into hordes and hordes of smaller spiders as you shoot them, etc. Shoot them until they die. Collect better weapons and power-ups they leave behind. Level up. Kill more of them with your bigger, shootier weapons until they overrun and kill you. Rinse. Repeat. 
     Yes, there are quests, but they only exist to give you more stuff with which to kill monsters in the Survival modes. Each quest you complete unlocks a new weapon or Perk (perks are specific character benefits you choose when you kill enough monsters to level up; like exploding when you die, shooting fireballs when you reload, shooting smaller fireball every few seconds, shooting one big fireball every few seconds... you get the idea). These facilitate your blowing up of stuff in subsequent games. No story or dialogue at all, but this game really doesn't need any. Crimsonland is about the simple joy of holding down the left mouse button, emptying your Rocket Minigun's 16-round magazine in three-odd seconds, and watching critters explode like blood-and-meat-filled balloons.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992278220', 'num_games_owned': 124, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 6883, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1710923711}
review:
It is a fun, fast paced top-down shooter with plenty of weapons, perks and masses of aliens. 

If you bought the old version, all you need is a proof of purchase and this enhanced version is yours for free.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976429810', 'num_games_owned': 282, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1438530426}
review:
Do you like shooting things? Do you like trying to beat your own highscore? Do you like overpowered combinations of abilities? Buy this game!

Shoot aliens, get powerups, shoot more aliens, get better powerups, keep shooting until you can't keep up. Simple but very fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046509845', 'num_games_owned': 284, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1180, 'last_played': 1649065396}
review:
I changed my mind with what I said before. One of my favorite parts of Crimsonland was the whole leveling up system on the quest mode, when I found out that it "has been removed" I flipped and instantly disliked it. BUT there is an overcome frome that, press escape when in a quest level and type "GRIM" (without the apstraphe) 

I like the fact that some of the enemys and guns look slighlty different while keeping the same great soundtrack and noises. 


P.S If you use the perk "regression bullets" you would pretty much be unsopable, it is made for survival, it makes it so you can shoot while reloading, but of course while you are in quest mode there isn't any points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017998493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1353, 'last_played': 1461412575}
review:
It could have been a good game but you'll find that this game has, as we say in the business, a "difficulty wall", meaning that all the game is more or less simple untill, out of the blue, you'll encounter a nearly impossible-frustrating level that will lock you there. I'm not talking about a very difficult level, I'm talking about a level that reaquires all the planets to be alinged in order for you to beat it. It's not SKILL hard, it's tedious and frustrating so much that after 500 attemps you are wondering "what the hell am I doing here?". It has the same thing in Survival Mode, basicaly impossible to get to level 7 (3, maybe 4 minutes of gameplay). You just can't, the amount of enemies and the lack of firepower will make it just mathematicaly impossible to go beyond level 6 unless, of course, the planets alling and you get the PERFECT combo of weapon/perks/powerups.
Another aspect that goes beyond reason is the fact that ALL the monsters (zombies included) have the best targeting system in the world and could easily be integrated in the AA missile for jet fighters, let me explain: the monsters will not point AT you, they will point at your vector, meaning they will go where you WILL BE calculating your speed and their ones, therefor you'll be ALLWAYS surrounded by monsters. What's that? A wonderful life-saving powerup? Let's go get it... but you can't because all the monsters will create a BLOCKADE in front of you because of the aforementioned targeting system, even the zombies, the quintessential STUPID being can collimate with you like the best soldier with Direct Hit.

Sorry but no, not worth the money, if it was free I would gladly suggest it to you worning you of the game killing problems... but PAYING for this? No, sorry, no.

review:

You can watch the time tick away as you fire away the multitude of weapons and pick up powerups in your quest to cover the screen in blood and earn many points

author: {'steamid': '76561198056067759', 'num_games_owned': 1791, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 1719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1657, 'last_played': 1523780945}
review:
If you're hardcore fan of the old crimson land avoid this remake as plague.

New UI just plain sucks, it feels so blunt and useless it's not fun at all.
The overburdened cross-hair is not usable, no common place for timers. Digits to figure remaining time. And all for sake of useless hot-seat multiplayer.

Not recommended until old interface is brought back at least as the "GRIM" option. 
Oh and i'm not buying Crimsonland 2 until this mess is fixed.

UPDATE:
Survival mode is now completely wasted. It's possible to get only like 6-7 perks, while  gameplay still relies on bonuses. So if you weren't lucky to get Bonus Magent and Bonus Economist just restart. In old CL bad random perks were affecting you in like 10% of games, now they do in 99% as most of them are worhless. This game is pathetic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019698275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 460, 'last_played': 1586351009}
{'steamid': '76561198003721210', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 496, 'last_played': 1482240340}
review:
Good, Bloody, Challenging, "Just-as-good-as-it-was-before", Diverse...

List can go on and on, however you can not link words to define the gameplay, Crimsonland, on the other hand, can!

Kill frist couple thousands of aliens and you will understand what I am talking about.

And dont you worry about Reaper - he will eventually get us all!)

A must have game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969415404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1491, 'last_played': 1707585389}
review: Only a few things...I'm number 85 in the world for high score in surviavl. Suck it try and beat me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028007451', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1763, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1478966415}
review:
Significantly harder than the previous versions. Aliens are smarter, levels are gained less often (and not in quests), perks are reworked (telekinetic is near useless now), new weapons, new powerups, better graphic.
It is still the old cool crimsonland, but now it has the steam convenience factor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994104902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1375, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1087, 'last_played': 1403766348}
review: Very hardcore and challenging game. On two levels difficulty is overwhelming, but this doesn't really spoil the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970057929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1549737707}
review: Owned this game since 2004 and it's still fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033496629', 'num_games_owned': 239, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 786, 'last_played': 1633953662}
review: The quintessential top-down shooter. Lots perks and weapons give it a mix RPG and arcade elements and makes it a hell of a lot of fun. Lack of online-coop is definetly missed though. At least the devs managed to expand the local coop to from 2 to 4. 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988482361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 358, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1666830316}
review:
Good ol' Crimsonland.
Tons of blood and dead bodies, bunch of perks... Perfect for brainless arcade shooting!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030512907', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 27478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 91, 'last_played': 1684587713}
review:
*Immer noch ein gutes Spiel*

Als Crimsonland vor einer gefÃ¼hlten Ewigkeit verÃ¶ffentlicht wurde, war ich ein begeisterter Spieler. Ob allein oder im Co-Op-Modus - das Spiel wurde einfach nicht langweilig. Jedes Level ist kurzweilig und gerade fÃ¼r Neulinge ist es spannend, welche abgefahrenen Waffen, Perks oder Extras als nÃ¤chstes freigeschalten werden.

Das Spiel ist absolut aufs wesentliche reduziert: Waffen, Monster, Blut, fertig. Nicht mehr und nicht weniger.

Die neue SpieloberflÃ¤che finde ich nicht so gelungen. Vom Flair des Originals ist da nichts mehr. Vielleicht ist es aber auch einfach zu viel Nostalgie, die mitschwingt, wenn man das alte MenÃ¼, Programm-Icon usw. vermisst. Vieles, wie z.B. die Map- und Monster-Grafiken, haben sich ja auch verbessert. 

Lediglich das leidige Thema Cheating scheint bei der Online-Hiscore-Liste auch nach 10 Jahren nicht behoben. Aber wer dieses Spiel spielt, spielt es nicht wegen der Hiscore-Liste. Sondern, weil es einfach SpaÃŸ macht.

Somit wÃ¼rde ich das Spiel jederzeit weiterempfehlen und hoffe, dass einen mit kommenden Updates noch Verbesserungen erwarten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000683981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1403287552}
review: Old school shoot-em up, simple, fast, but be aware, it have some critical difficulty spikes, some mission in quest mode (to unlock game content) can take x10-1000 more time then most mission before. Due this difficulty spikes i sure this game is annoyance winner of 2014 :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198096305352', 'num_games_owned': 704, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 178, 'last_played': 1403176906}
review:
Ah, i sure was surprised seeing Crimsonland here on Steam. Its a real blast-from-the-past, back from the times when i did not care about fancy graphics, realistic physics and whatsoever, and just enjoyed the simplistic and somewhat primal kind of fun, which Crimsonland soundly provided. 
Yes, it is kinda short. Yes, you can clear it within a day. But what a day it will be!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006648510', 'num_games_owned': 1324, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 7936, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1277, 'last_played': 1522180747}
review:
I was 12 when this game originally came out, I loved it then and I still love it now.

The remaster adds support for modern resolutions along with some minor graphical upgrades and a little extra game content, but I'm honestly just really happy to see this game on Steam in the first place - gratuitous top-down violence never felt so good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980241818', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2041, 'last_played': 1538515485}
review:
9/10

Damals wie heute ein echt geiles Game! Die solide Steuerung, das Waffenverhalten und die garstig gute KI sorgen fÃ¼r ein angenehm forderndes Spielerlebnis. Der neue Content, hÃ¤lt genug Stoff fÃ¼r viele spaÃŸige Spielstunden bereit und ist auf Grund der vielen verschiedenen Missionen sehr abwechslungsreich. Das Niveau der Grafik und die geschmeidigen Animationen lassen die meisten anderen top-down shooter sehr sehr alt aussehen, was nur einer der GrÃ¼nde ist, warum es fÃ¼r mich immernoch der unangefochtene Meister dieses Genres ist. Auch die neu implemtierte ControllerunterstÃ¼tzung, welche nun lokales Coop mit 3 weiteren Spielern ermÃ¶glicht, ist ein schÃ¶nes feature, bei dem man sich gemeinsam den RÃ¼cken deckend durch die Massen schieÃŸen kann^^.

Warum nur 9/10?
So sehr ich dieses Spiel empfehlen kann, finde ich fÃ¼r ein Rework den Preis von 14â‚¬ ein bisschen happig.
Maximal 10 Euronen hÃ¤tte ich als Preis angesetzt. FÃ¼r alle die bei Spielen nicht nur auf den Preis schauen, ist es

author: {'steamid': '76561197977524987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 3084, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 688, 'last_played': 1689080406}
review: This will be as short and sweet as possible. In its current state this is 'mostly' the Crimsonland you may remember and love with changes that seem to add a finer level of polish to what could be said to be a progenitor of 'Arena Shooters. To boil Crimsonland's experience down to single word "cathartic" will suffice. You can begrudge differences from past versions or claim there is not enough change at all... but any game that has stood the test of time this well against a veritable mountain of copycats is worthy of your time and at half the price this title originally sold for. Enjoy it thoroughly for it will devour your time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198105557587', 'num_games_owned': 399, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1537905744}

author: {'steamid': '76561197963338879', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 3166, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2364, 'last_played': 1496558247}
review:
Crimsonland is an awesome game, and so are the devs.

I've been playing Crimsonland since it came out in 2003 (over 10 years ago!) and it is still as much fun today as it was back then. This HD remake has everything I loved about the original Crimsonland and more.

Yes, there are changes from the original version, but I feel that these were in good taste. One of the biggest changes I've noticed is that telekinesis no longer lets you selectively pick up powerups. Instead, it pulls all nearby powerups to you.

Additionally, Typ'o'Shooter is nowhere to be found. This was one of my favorite modes and I REALLY hope that it gets brought back in an update.

The gameplay is as insane as it was in 2003, if not moreso. There are so many enemies on the screen sometimes that it's hard to comprehend, and yet the game never skips a beat. The monsters now gib when you kill them, and this effect looks really great.

Although online multiplayer would propel Crimsonland to new levels of awesomeness, the couch co-op is a ton of fun. I just tried it for the first time with a couple friends and we had a blast. The game scales the difficulty based on how many players there are, so be prepared for even more carnage.

All in all, this is mostly the same game it was back in 2003 but with updated graphics and a few (good) tweaks here and there. As a player of the original Crimonsland, I highly recommend this game to fans and newcomers alike. Speaking of which; if you've never played Crimsonland, do youself a favor and buy this game right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037222425', 'num_games_owned': 955, 'num_reviews': 241, 'playtime_forever': 818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1516430477}
review:
YES!

The coolest of the top down arena shooters is back!

If you like games like Nuclear Throne, see the game that clearly inspired it.

Take on ENDLESS HORDES of zombies, lizardmen, ants, spiders, and other unspeakable thingies and send them back into the abyss from which they came with a huge variety of over the top weapons and wacky perks.

If already a fan of the original game, you'll see it is all there plus some new game modes and possibly other perks and weapons as well (not positive on this).

One very cool new game mode is all about trying to see how long you can last without any weapons but only the games few power-ups to keep you going (like Nuke and Fireblast), a very fun and original mode that really forces you to adapt to a constantly shifting playfield.

review: I purchased this game years ago, and have played it on and off for the last 5+ years, it has always been fun for a mindless shoot-em-up arcade style game, They have improved the local co-op, unfortunately I have been unable to get my controller recognized as of yet, but as I am the only person at the computer, that is no real issue, yet. The one thing I miss from the old version is the ability to gain perks while going through the quest mode.

Si ya habÃ­as jugando antes Crimsonland estarÃ¡s familiarizado con el frenÃ©tico estÃ­lo del juego y las subidas de adrenalina que provoca tratar de destruir a 300 monstruos en pantalla a balazos. Esta versiÃ³n retocada mantiene eso y apenas cambia al juego en sÃ­. Los grÃ¡ficos han mejorado mucho y la interfaz es mÃ¡s moderna mientras que se mantienen y aÃ±aden unas cuantas armas.

Los modos de juego del original se mantienen y no cambian mucho, lo Ãºnico distinto de la campaÃ±a por ejemplo es que ya no se pueden usar las "perks" y se han vuelto exclusivas del modo supervivencia. A parte de este detalle que, si bien no es de mi agrado no altera mucho la experiencia, el juego merece ser comprado.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986703709', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1313, 'last_played': 1492849757}
review:
[h1] Ver. 1.2.3: Survival is back [/h1]

This game is a remake/improved verison of the original Crimsonland game, which I absolutely loved and spent hours trying to get a decent score in Survival Mode. I instantly bought this one when it was released, and while I liked it at first, I had to give it a thumb down after couple of dozens runs in Survival. My main issues with the game were:

1) Low camera altitude: can't see the field of battle clearly
2) New perk and experience system: no perks in quests (kinda), leveling up is extremely slow, some important perks altered for worse.
3) Interface: power-ups are displayed on crosshair, hp and shield are displayed on player model.
4) Survival Mode: added monster-spawners, average game longevity is ~3 times shorter than in original game, harder to get a weapon you want.

After update 1.1.0, review was changed to positive, mostly because of the inclusion of original Crimslonland game for free. Changes to he game were good, but not good enough, since it didn't fix the main issue with survival mode: toned down exp gains in comparison to the old game, which resulted in very short survival matches, without any feel of buliding up your character.

But now with update 1.2.3 I can totally recommend this one. Increased exp gains and some changes to perks made the game as enjoyable as the original. While in previous versions you died on level 6-7 (my personal highscore was around 350k points), now level 30 is not even impressive (50+ million points is pretty much a real thing). Of course, you're still pretty much screwed, unless you get at least few of the vital perks in first ten levels, but overall, now this game wrecks you with RNG (in terms of obtaining perks, weapons and power-ups) even less than the original did.

Final thoughts:

A great top-down shooter, with the potential to suck you in for dozens of hours, if you're into getting the high scores. The "story" mode (i.e. quests) is more of a training ground before survival, so I don't think it's worth to buy the game if you don't plan on playing survival. But if you do, prepare for absolute carnage, because Crimsonland is finally back.

P.S. Took more than 2.5 years though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969035830', 'num_games_owned': 206, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 1889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1049, 'last_played': 1405159759}
review:
[h1]Still as fun as ever![/h1]
I didn't know the game was even being remade, but saw it in the store by accident and bought it straight away and despite my doubts, still love it after playing the original all those years ago. It's not the same game as back then but it's bigger and better than ever.

A must buy for any fan of brainless shooting and digital massacre. 10/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996527741', 'num_games_owned': 489, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 233, 'last_played': 1479948656}
review:
If you've played Crimsonland before, this is essentially the same game from a decade ago with some minor changes. The graphics and UI have been (slightly) updated, and some great new weapons, perks, and powerups have been added. The most notable changes are the removal of perks from the campaign mode and the addition of monster spawners/nests in survival mode, both of which make the game more challenging (in a good way).

If you're new to Crimsonland, this is a fairly straightforward top-town shooter in which you use outlandish weapons and powerups to...well, paint the map crimson. The gameplay is similar to Serious Sam's, in the sense that you'll be constantly circle-strafing around enemies to avoid getting overrun. Don't think to hard, and you'll have a great time. The original game was always a guilty pleasure of mine, and I'm glad that Greenlight has made this subtlely remastered version possible.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970495259', 'num_games_owned': 2161, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1498653574}
review: This right here is the first good indie game, with a bunch of improvements over the 2003 version. Shit is very awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019022165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 253, 'last_played': 1402529868}
review:
Nice carnage game in the spirit of gauntlet if you remember this old arcade game. You got hordes of monsters to kill and more come up all the time. You can use one weapon only but by killing monsters you can get random other weapons (and there are a loooooot of them) and powerups (for a limited time). You can also get a nuclear bomb that kill everything in a blast radius.

The graphic are pretty simple(hey the game is only 80MB!) and there is a lot of blood spatter. The view is top down. You can play the campaign which unlocks perks that you can use when playing survival mode. 

It's a simple game with a lot of carnage, so its good for doing that. The price is a bit steep at 9$, i would suggest waiting until it falls down to 5$ to but it tought

author: {'steamid': '76561198015584380', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1432676084}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029281191', 'num_games_owned': 1428, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 477, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1655195645}
review:
1. No perks in quest mode? Seriously?
Even with the [spoiler] GRIM [/spoiler] code unlocking perks in quest mode, the length of each level still makes perks very useless. The point of whole game for me is to shoot monsters, gain EXP and grow stronger with perks.

2. Telekinisis pulls unwanted weapons. Have you ever seen such a badass guy chased by a small blowtorch and have no where to run before?

3. Saving perks such as bandage or breathing room for emergency usage in survival mode is no longer a valid strategy.

4. Nests are spawned randomly in survival mode now, which makes the game even more unpredictable. 

5. The old version had a larger view range, even larger than this new version with the eagle eye perk (or whatever name the perk is called, i can't remember exactly).

Sorry 10tons, but playing the new Crimsonland just make me wanna play the old version more and more.

(sorry for my poor english, it is a second language for me.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197976127600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1516636394}
review:
This may be a little bit of an early review and I'll probably update it regarding the survival modes and other bits that may have been tweaked, but I played the original non-steam version of this game for more hours than I dare to count... So far it seems that everything that made this game great is there and tighter than ever.

This game has loads of fun weapons, loads of interesting perks, sharp graphics, local multiplayer and more enemies than you can shake a stick at. Rock solid entertainment if you just want to switch off and blast hordes of badguys into chunks of red.

These guys are also super nice, they gave me the steam version for free when I provided them proof of purchase from way back in the day which I found hidden away in my inbox. A lot of companies would have just let people re-buy it for profit, instead they're sending out e-mails manually to help their fans out while apologizing for the slight delay.. I got mine within a couple of days and simply can't complain and I wish them all the best.

Time to eat some bandages and make the lands crimson all over again!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073092621', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1455197405}
review:
Mit einer tiefgrÃ¼ndigen Geschichte kann Crimsonland nicht dienen, was aber auch niemand erwartet, denn hier geht es nur um folgende Dinge: TÃ¶ten, Ãœberleben, Verbessern. Sollten aber dennoch ein paar Pedanten auf eine Zusammenfassung bestehen, so kann man diesen Filme wie Starship Troopers ans Herz legen. Eine Art Soldat sitzt auf einem Planeten fest und kÃ¤mpft sich durch eine Horde Insekten, Eidechsen und Mutantenwesen und versucht zu Ã¼berleben.

Crimsonland bietet dem Spieler zunÃ¤chst den Quest-Modus an, bei dem man 6 verschiedene Welten mit je zehn Missionen durchspielen kann. Pro Mission werden einem dabei verschiedene Waffen vorgestellt. WÃ¤hrend den ersten Missionen schaltet man den Survival-Modus frei, bei dem es, wie der Name schon sagt, darum geht, so lange wie mÃ¶glich zu Ã¼berleben. Dort hat man die Waffen zur VerfÃ¼gung, die man im Quest-Modus freigeschaltet hat. Dies gilt auch fÃ¼r Perks, die im Prinzip wie Skill-Punkte funktionieren. Hat man eine gewisse Anzahl an Erfahrungspunkte gesammelt, kann man aus den freigespielten SpezialfÃ¤higkeiten, wie zum Beispiel dem schnelleres Nachladen von Waffen, auswÃ¤hlen. Aber Ãœberleben ist nicht gleich Ãœberleben. Dies ist in Crimsonland auf fÃ¼nf verschiedene Arten mÃ¶glich. WÃ¤hrend man im normalen Survival-Modus Welle fÃ¼r Welle Ã¼berstehen muss, geht es im Rush-Modus darum, ohne Erfahrungspunkte und nach Sekunden zu Ã¼berleben, wÃ¤hrend von Anfang an schon riesige Horden von Gegnern auf einen zustÃ¼rmen. 

Grafisch gesehen hat sich Crimsonland gegenÃ¼ber dem Original-Titel kaum verÃ¤ndert, was aber auch nicht weiter problematisch ist, sondern den Charme des Spiels unterstÃ¼zt. Das Spiel prÃ¤sentiert sich in einer GTA 2-Optik, bei der vor allem die Farbe Rot im Vordergrund steht. Teilweise war beim Spielen der Boden so blutig, dass ebenfalls rote Gegner darauf nicht mehr erkennbar waren. Die etwas Ã¤ltere Grafik hat den Vorteil, dass Crimsonland selbst auf ganz alten PCs und sogar Laptops einwandfrei lÃ¤uft, selbst wenn der Bildschirm voll von Insekten und Eidechsen ist.

Die Steuerung gestaltet sich klassisch mit WASD und der Maus. Controller werden ebenfalls unterstÃ¼zt, sollten allerdings nur zweite Wahl sein, oder unbeliebten Freunden in die Hand gedrÃ¼ckt werden, da sich die Steuerung per Gamepad als sehr ungenau und anstrengend erweist. Appropos Freunde: SÃ¤mtliche Modi sind auch im Co-op mit bis zu vier Spielern mÃ¶glich. Dies allerdings nur Lokal am heimischen Rechner und nicht online oder Ã¼ber ein Netzwerk. Schade, mit einer Online-Funktion hÃ¤tte der Titel sicherlich noch einmal einen ganz anderen SpielspaÃŸ hervorgerufen.

Crimsonland bietet eine Menge SpielspaÃŸ, der Ã¼ber Stunden hinweg beschÃ¤ftigen kann. Da spielt es auch keine Rolle, ob das Spiel nur ein simples Remake des zehn Jahre alten Originals ist. Vor allem im Co-op macht der Top-Down-Shooter richtig Laune, was es um so trauriger macht, dass kein Online-Modus unterstÃ¼tzt wird. Retro ist ja gut und schÃ¶n, aber manche Dinge sollten im Jahr 2014 dann doch angepasst werden. Trotzdem, Crimsonland ist ein Spiel, das einfach fetzt und begeistert. (Und fÃ¼r das momentane Angebot von 8,39â‚¬ (bis zum 18. Juni) kann man auf jeden Fall zuschlagen.)

Wir geben dem Titel 73%.
FÃ¼r weitere Reviews besucht uns auf www.gamers.de

review: Ğ”Ğ»Ñ Ñ‚ĞµÑ… ĞºÑ‚Ğ¾ Ğ½Ğµ Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ¸Ñ‚ Ğ±Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞ¸Ğµ Ğ¾Ğ±Ğ·Ğ¾Ñ€Ñ‹ - Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¨ĞµĞ´ĞµĞ²Ñ€ Ñ Ğ‘Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒÑˆĞ¾Ğ¹ Ğ‘ÑƒĞºĞ²Ñ‹! ĞŸĞ¾ĞºÑƒĞ¿Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ, Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ğ°Ñ‚ÑŒ, ÑÑ€Ğ¾Ñ‡Ğ½Ğ¾!

author: {'steamid': '76561198045446084', 'num_games_owned': 602, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1675536687}
review:
It's finaly nice to have this legend in Steam also. However there are some features in this new remake version which I have ...even despise.
- First of all, why on earth it is not any longer possible to level-up and use perks in the quests!?
- The Progress bar in the quests is pretty annoying. In my opinion it should be much smaller.
- The new healthbar and reload system doesn't look very pretty although I understand the point behind it: the player doesn't need to take his eyes off of the player when there is alot of action.
- In the survival, it is absolutely horrible when you can't no longer deside yourself when to pick a perk after leveling. There is usually very much action going on and therefore sudden pop-up windows can really ruin the game session.
- I mainly play the game by myself, so the "Press fire to join" infos in each corner are very irritating.

After all that complaining, there are also good new features.
- It is nice how you must unlock the weapons and perks in the quests to be able to use them in the Survival.
- The menus are more graphical, although somewhat crude-looking. (And some menus lack some buttons I'd presume to be there; like replay after winning a level)
- Now it is possible to see each wepon's individual specs.
- The star ranking in in each level (for beating it without taking a hit) adds playability a bit more. However I would like to have even more achieavables (stars) per level, like for instance >40% accuracy or complete the level under par time.
- Four player co-op is nice! (hopefully in the future it will be possible over the net)

All in all it is close to the good old legendary Crimsonland, but I don't completely agree with the new change choises the 10ton team has made. Alse the 14â‚¬ price is somewhat steep (at least in my and my wallet's oppinion).

author: {'steamid': '76561198014486748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1642969518}
review:
I never played the original Crimsonland. Well actually that's not true; I tried the demo once and the game didn't really seem like anything special. After reading some great impressions from a friend, I decided to check out this new and improved Crimsonland and I'm very glad I did. It's addictive, bloody, intense, and just one hell of a fun satisfying shooter.

In terms of story and gameplay, Crimsonland is as simple as can be. You and hordes of hundreds and hundreds of creatures on the battlefield, kill them all. But while the actual mechanics are not complex, Crimsonland adds a layer of strategy underneath the run and gun gameplay, turning a game that might seem shallow from the screenshots into a compelling thrilling experience. Every moment consists of countless decisions. Which gun is best for the current situation? Should I rush for that power-up but risk having to run through a horde to reach it? Which order should I use power-ups? Which perks should I choose?

I think the most interesting aspect is how the varied enemies require you to totally change your tactics and influences the weapons and perks you'd want to use. It's not like some shooters where you can just get the most powerful weapon and kill everything. If you're facing fast spiders that replicate when they die, then you're going to want a weapon that's accurate and precise but that fires and reloads fast enough that they won't close the gap, and power-ups that focus on crowd control and defense. Hordes of zombies? You'll want to go for the spray and pray type weapons or explosives and all-out offensive power-ups. Thankfully your arsenal is just as varied as the enemies you face. Weapons range from a simple pistol and shotgun to all manner of flamethrowers, plasma cannons, automatic weapons, and even more exotic weapons. Power-ups slow time, shield you from damage, restore health, imbue your weapon with devastating plasma energy. The RPG-esque perk system offers diverse ways to customize your playstyle. Sacrifice health for damage, move faster, have more ammo, poison enemies, gain a melee attack, and many more perks make each survival attempt feel fresh and exciting

Crimsonland is a must play for top-down shooter fans. Besides the 60-mission campaign (and three difficulty levels), you can test your skills across several survival modes, all of which adds its own twist of the core gameplay. The visuals and effects are stylish, the gameplay is deeper than you'd might expect, and seeing the screen literally turn red with blood and gore as you mow down hundreds of creatures is very satisfying.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982670363', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1708798106}
review:
This is one of the best top-down shooters I have ever played.

A couple of months ago I've learned that 10tons, the developers of the original Crimsonland, are making an enhanced version of the game and are bringing it to Steam (and also PS4). Needless to say, I was very excited. I have played it way back in 2004, and at the time I didn't even have the opportunity to obtain it legally (I live in Russia, and back in 2004 the digital distribution model was unknown to an average Russian gamer). And now, 10 years later, it's a perfect chance for me to thank the developers by buying a copy of a game I really love.

The gameplay is self-explanatory and very fun. You've got a gun and countless hordes of monsters on the screen - the rest is up to you. By using different weapons and perks you shoot your way through till you're the last man standing.

The highlight of the game for me is the Survival mode. In this mode, you fight against infinite waves of enemies, using perks and weapons unlocked in the main campaign.

This edition of the game has revamped UI - personally, I love it - it's nice, clean, and suits the game pretty well.

All this also comes with the support of HD resolutions, it's great to finally enjoy the game in 1080p instead of the original 800x600.

All in all, it's a classic, modernised and refined for the current generation of gamers and those, who like me, have nostalgic memories of playing this game as a kid :3
